castItem.roleDesc: a boy; a son to Page

div2.head: SCENE I
div2.stage: Enter JUSTICE SHALLOW, SLENDER, and SIR HUGH EVANS.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Sir Hugh, persuade me not; I will
make a
Star-chamber matter of it: if he were
twenty Sir
John Falstaffs, he shall not abuse
Robert Shallow,
esquire.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
In the county of Gloucester, justice
of peace and 'Coram.'

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Ay, cousin Slender, and 'Custalorum.'

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Ay, and 'Rato-lorum' too; and a
gentleman born,
master parson; who writes
himself 'Armigero,' in any
bill, warrant, quittance,
or obligation, 'Armigero.'

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Ay, that I do; and have done any
time these three
hundred years.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
All his successors gone before him
hath done't;
and all his ancestors that come
after him may: they
may give the dozen white
luces in their coat.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: It is an old coat.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
The dozen white louses do become
an old
coat well; it agrees well, passant; it is
a familiar beast to
man, and signifies love.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
The luce is the fresh fish; the salt
fish is an old
coat.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I may quarter, coz.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: You may, by marrying.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p: It is marring indeed, if he quarter it.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Not a whit.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Yes, py'r lady; if he has a quarter
of your coat,
there is but three skirts for yourself,
in my simple conjectures:
but that is all
one. If Sir John Falstaff have
committed disparagements
unto you, I am of the church,
and will be glad to do my benevolence to make
atonements
and compremises between you.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: The council shall hear it; it is a riot.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
It is not meet the council hear a
riot; there
is no fear of Got in a riot: the
council, look you,
shall desire to hear the fear
of Got, and not to hear a
riot; take your vizaments
in that.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Ha! o' my life, if I were young again,
the sword
should end it.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
It is petter that friends is the sword,
and end
it: and there is also another device
in my prain, which
peradventure prings goot
discretions with it: there is
Anne Page, which
is daughter to Master Thomas Page,
which is
pretty virginity.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Mistress Anne Page? She has brown
hair, and
speaks small like a woman.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
It is that fery person for all the
orld, as just as
you will desire; and seven hundred
pounds of moneys,
and gold and silver,
is her grandsire upon his death's-bed
--Got
deliver to a joyful resurrections!--give, when
she is able to overtake seventeen years old:
it were a
goot motion if we leave our pribbles
and prabbles, and
desire a marriage between
Master Abraham and Mistress
Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Did her grandsire leave her seven
hundred
pound?

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Ay, and her father is make her a
petter penny.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I know the young gentlewoman; she
has good
gifts.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Seven hundred pounds and possibilities
is
goot gifts.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Well, let us see honest Master Page.
Is Falstaff there?

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Shall I tell you a lie? I do despise
a liar as I
do depise one that is false, or as I
despise one that is not
true. The knight, Sir
John, is there; and, I beseech you, be
ruled by
your well-willers. I will peat the door for Master

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
What, hoa! Got pless your
house here!

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
[Within] Who's there!
Enter PAGE.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Here is Got's plessing, and your
friend, and Justice
Shallow; and here young
Master Slender, that peradventures
shall tell
you another tale, if matters grow to
your
likings.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
I am glad to see your worships well.
I
thank you for my venison, Master Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Master Page, I am glad to see you:
much good
do it your good heart! I wished
your venison better; it
was ill killed. How doth
good Mistress Page?--and I thank
you always
with my heart, la! with my heart.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Sir, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Sir, I thank you; by yea and no, I do.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
I am glad to see you, good Master
Slender.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
How does your fallow greyhound,
sir? I heard
say he was outrun on Cotsall.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: It could not be judged, sir.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: You'll not confess, you'll not confess.

sp.speaker: Shal.
Page.
sp.p: A cur, sir.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Sir, he's a good dog, and a fair dog:
can there
be more said? he is good and fair.
Is Sir John Falstaff
here?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Sir, he is within; and I would I
could do a
good office between you.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
It is spoke as a Christians ought to
speak.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: He hath wronged me, Master Page.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Sir, he doth in some sort confess it.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
If it be confessed, it is not redressed:
is not that
so, Master Page? He hath wronged
me; indeed he hath; at a
word, he hath, believe
me: Robert Shallow, esquire, saith,
he is
wronged.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Here comes Sir John.
Enter SIR JOHN FALSTAFF, BARDOLPH, NYM and PISTOL.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Now, Master Shallow, you'll complain
of me to
the king?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Knight, you have beaten my men,
killed my
deer, and broke open my lodge.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: But not kissed your keeper's daughter?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Tut, a pin! this shall be answered.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I will answer it straight, I have done all this.
That is now answered.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: The council shall know this.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
'Twere better for you if it were known
in counsel:
you'll be laughed at.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p: Pauca verba, Sir John; goot worts.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Good worts! good cabbage. Slender,
I broke
your head: what matter have you
against me?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Marry, sir, I have matter in my head
against you;
and against your cony-catching
rascals, Bardolph, Nym,
and Pistol.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: You Banbury cheese!

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Ay, it is no matter.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: How now, Mephostophilus!

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Ay, it is no matter.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p:
Slice, I say! pauca, pauca: slice!
that's my humor.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Where's Simple, my man? Can you
tell, cousin?

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Peace, I pray you. Now let us understand.
There
is three umpires in this matter,
as I understand; that is,
Master Page,
fidelicet Master Page; and there is myself,
fidelicet myself; and the three party is, lastly
and finally,
mine host of the Garter.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
We three, to hear it and end it between
them.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Fery goot: I will make a prief of
it in my
note-book; and we will afterwards ork
upon the cause
with as great discreetly as we
can.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Pistol!

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: He hears with ears.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
The tevil and his tam! what phrase
is this,
'He hears with ear'? why, it is
affectations.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Pistol, did you pick Master Slender's
purse?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Ay, by these gloves, did he, or I
would I might
never come in mine own great
chamber again else, of
seven groats in
mill-sixpences, and two Edward shovel-boards,
that
cost me two shilling and two pence a-piece
of
Yead Miller, by these gloves.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Is this true, Pistol?

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p: No; it is false, if it is a pick-purse.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l:
Ha, thou mountain-foreigner! Sir John and
master mine,
I combat challenge of this latten bilbo.
Word of denial in thy labras here!

Word of denial; froth
and scum, thou liest!

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: By these gloves, then, 'twas he.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p:
Be avised, sir, and pass good humors:
I will
say 'marry trap' with you, if you
run the nuthook's humour
on me; that is the
very note of it.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
By this hat, then, he in the red face
had it; for
though I cannot remember what I
did when you made
me drunk, yet I am not
altogether an ass.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: What say you, Scarlet and John?

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p:
Why, sir, for my part, I say the gentleman
had
drunk himself out of his five
sentences.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
It is his five senses: fie, what the
ignorance is!

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p:
And being fap, sir, was, as they say,
cashiered; and
so conclusions passed the
careires.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Ay, you spake in Latin then too; but
'tis no matter:
I'll ne'er be drunk whilst I live
again, but in honest,
civil, godly company, for
this trick: if I be drunk, I'll
be drunk with
those that have the fear of God, and not
with
drunken knaves.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
So Got udge me, that is a virtuous
mind.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
You hear all these matters denied,
gentlemen;
you hear it.
Enter ANNE PACE, with wine; MISTRESS FORD and MISTRESS PAGE, following.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Nay, daughter, carry the wine in;

we'll 
drink within.

[Exit Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: O heaven! this is Mistress Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: How now, Mistress Ford!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Mistress Ford, by my troth, you are
very well met:
by your leave, good mistress.
[Kisses her.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Wife, bid these gentlemen welcome:
Come,
we have a hot venison pasty to dinner:
come, gentlemen,
I hope we shall drink down
all unkindness.
[Exeunt all except Shal., Slen., and Evans.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I had rather than forty shillings I had
my Book
of Songs and Sonnets here.
Enter SIMPLE.
How now, Simple! where
have you been? I
must wait on myself, must I? You
have not
the Book of Riddles about you, have you?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
Book of Riddles! why, did you not
lend it to
Alice Shortcake upon All-hallowmas
last, a fortnight afore
Michaelmas?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Come, coz; come, coz; we stay for
you. A word
with you, coz; marry, this, coz:
there is, as 'twere, a tender,
a kind of tender,
made afar off by Sir Hugh here.
Do you
understand me?

sp.speaker: Slen.
Shal.
sp.p: Nay, but understand me.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: So I do, sir.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Give ear to his motions, Master
Slender: I will
description the matter to you,
if you be capacity of it.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Nay, I will do as my cousin Shallow
says: I
pray you, pardon me; he's a justice of
peace in his country,
simple though I stand
here.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
But that is not the question: the
question is
concerning your marriage.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Ay, there's the point, sir.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Marry, is it; the very point of it;
to Mistress Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Why, if it be so, I will marry her
upon any reasonable
demands.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
But can you affection the 'oman?
Let us command
to know that of your mouth
or of your lips; for divers
philosophers hold
that the lips is parcel of the mouth.
Therefore,
precisely, can you carry your good will to the
maid?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Cousin Abraham Slender, can you love her?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I hope, sir, I will do as it shall become
one that
would do reason.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Nay, Got's lords and his ladies! you
must speak
possitable, if you can carry her
your desires towards her.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
That you must.
Will you, upon good
dowry, marry her?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I will do a greater thing than that,
upon your
request, cousin, in any reason.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Nay, conceive me, conceive me, sweet
coz:
what I do is to pleasure you, coz. Can
you love the
maid?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I will marry her, sir, at your request:
but if
there be no great love in the beginning,
yet heaven
may decrease it upon better acquaintance,
when we
are married and have
more occasion to know one another;
I hope,
upon familiarity will grow more contempt:
but if you say, 'Marry her,' I will marry her;
that I am freely
dissolved, and dissolutely.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
It is a fery discretion answer; save
the fall is in
the ort 'dissolutely:' the ort is,
according to our meaning,
'resolutely:' his
meaning is good.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Ay, I think my cousin meant well.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Ay, or else I would I might be hanged, la!

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l:
Here comes fair Mistress Anne.
Re-enter ANNE PAGE.

Would I were
young for your sake, Mistress Anne!

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p:
The dinner is on the table; my father
desires
your worships' company.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I will wait on him, fair Mistress Anne.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Od's plessed will! I will not be
absence at the grace.
[Exeunt Shallow, and Evans.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p:
Will 't please your worship to come
in, sir?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
No, I thank you, forsooth, heartily;
I am very well.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: The dinner attends you, sir.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I am not a-hungry, I thank you, forsooth.
Go,
sirrah, for all you are my man, go
wait upon my cousin
Shallow. [Exit Simple.]
A justice of peace sometime may be beholding
to his friend for a man. I keep but three
men and a
boy yet, till my mother be dead:
but what though? yet
I live like a poor
gentleman born.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p:
I may not go in without your worship:
they
will not sit till you come.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I' faith, I'll eat nothing; I thank you
as much as
though I did.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: I pray you, sir, walk in.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I had rather walk here, I thank you.
I bruised
my shin th' other day with playing
at sword and dagger
with a master of fence;
three veneys for a dish of
stewed prunes; and,
by my troth, I cannot abide the smell
of hot
meat since. Why do your dogs bark so? be
there bears i' the town?

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p:
I think there are, sir; I heard them
talked of.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I love the sport well; but I shall as
soon quarrel
at it as any man in England.
You are afraid, if you see the
bear loose, are
you not?

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: Ay, indeed, sir.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
That's meat and drink to me, now.
I have seen
Sackerson loose twenty times, and
have taken him by the
chain; but, I warrant
you, the women have so cried
and shrieked at
it, that it passed; but women, indeed, cannot
abide 'em; they are very ill-favoured rough
things.
Re-enter PAGE.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Come, gentle Master Slender, come;
we stay for you.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I'll eat nothing, I thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
By cock and pie, you shall not
choose, sir!
come, come.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Nay, pray you, lead the way.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Come on, sir.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Mistress Anne, yourself shall go first.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: Not I, sir: pray you, keep on.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Truly, I will not go first; truly, la!
I will not
do you that wrong.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: I pray you, sir.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I'll rather be unmannerly than troublesome.
You
do yourself wrong, indeed, la!
[Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE II
div2.stage: Enter SIR HUGH EVANS and SIMPLE.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Go your ways, and ask of Doctor
Caius' house
which is the way: and there
dwells one Mistress Quickly,
which is in the
manner of his nurse, or his dry nurse, or
his
cook, or his laundry, his washer, and his
wringer.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Well, sir.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Nay it is petter yet. Give her this
letter; for it is
a 'oman that altogether's acquaintance
with Mistress Anne
Page: and the
letter is, to desire and require her to solicit
your master's desires to Mistress Anne Page.
I pray
you, be gone: I will make an end of
my dinner; there's pippins
and cheese to come.
[Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE III
div2.stage: A room in the Garter Inn.
Enter FALSTAFF, HOST, BARDOLPH, NYM, PISTOL, and ROBIN.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Mine host of the Garter!

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
What says my bully-rook? speak
scholarly
and wisely.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Truly, mine host, I must turn away
some of my
followers.

sp.speaker: Host.
Fal.
sp.l: I sit at ten pounds a week.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Thou'rt an emperor, Caesar, Keisar,
and Pheezar.
I will entertain Bardolph; he
shall draw, he shall tap: said
I well, bully
Hector?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Do so, good mine host.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
I have spoke; let him follow.
[To Bard.] Let me see thee froth
and lime: I am
at a word; follow.
[Exit.

sp.speaker: Fal.
Bard.
sp.p:
It is a life that I have desired: I will
thrive.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
O base Hungarian wight! wilt thou
the spigot wield?
[Exit Bardolph.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p:
He was gotten in drink: is not the
humor conceited?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I am glad I am so acquit of this tinderbox:
his
thefts were too open; his filching
was like an unskilful
singer; he kept not time.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p:
The good humor is to steal at a
minute's rest.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
'Convey,' the wise it call. 'Steal!'
foh! a fico for
the phrase!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Well, sirs, I am almost out at heels.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Why, then, let kibes ensue.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
There is no remedy; I must conycatch;
I must shift.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Young ravens must have food.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Which of you know Ford of this town?

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
I ken the wight: he is of substance
good.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
My honest lads, I will tell you what I
am about.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Two yards, and more.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
No quips now, Pistol! Indeed, I am
in the waist
two yards about: but I am now
about no waste; I am about
thrift. Briefly, I
do mean to make love to Ford's
wife: I spy
entertainment in her; she discourses, she
carves, she gives the leer of invitation: I can
construe
the action of her familiar style; and
the hardest voice of her
behaviour, to be Englished
rightly, is, 'I am Sir John Falstaff's.'

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
He hath studied her will, and translated
her will,
out of honesty into English.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p:
The anchor is deep: will that
humor pass?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Now, the report goes she has all the
rule of her
husband's purse: he hath a legion
of angels.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
As many devils entertain; and 'To
her, boy,' say I.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p:
The humor rises; it is good: humor
me the angels.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I have writ me here a letter to her:
and here another
to Page's wife, who even now
gave me good eyes
too, examined my parts
with most judicious oeillades; sometimes
the
beam of her view gilded my foot, sometimes
my portly belly.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Then did the sun on dunghill shine.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: I thank thee for that humor.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
O, she did so course o'er my exteriors
with such
a greedy intention, that the appetite
of her eye did seem
to scorch me up like a
burning-glass! Here's another
letter to her:
she bears the purse too; she is a region
in
Guiana, all gold and bounty. I will be cheater
to
them both, and they shall be exchequers to
me; they
shall be my East and West Indies,
and I will trade to
them both. Go bear thou
this letter to Mistress Page;
and thou this to
Mistress Ford: we will thrive, lads, we
will
thrive.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Shall I Sir Pandarus of Troy become,
And by my side wear steel? then, Lucifer take all!

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p:
I will run no base humor: here,
take the humor-letter:
I will keep the havior
of reputation.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Hold, sirrah, bear you these letters tightly;
Sail like my pinnace to these golden shores.
Rogues, hence, avaunt! vanish like hailstones go:
Trudge, plod away o' the hoof; seek shelter, pack!
Falstaff will learn the humor of the age,

French thrift, you rogues; myself and skirted page.
[Exeunt Falstaff and Robin.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l:
Let vultures gripe thy guts! for gourd and
fullam holds,
And high and low beguiles the rich and poor:
Tester I'll have in pouch when thou shalt lack,
Base Phrygian Turk!

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p:
I have operations
which be humours
of revenge.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Wilt thou revenge?

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: By welkin and her star!

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: With wit or steel?

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: With both the humors, I:
I will discuss the humor of this love to Page.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: And I to Ford shall eke unfold
How Falstaff varlet vile,
His dove will prove, his gold will hold,
And his soft couch defile.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p:
My humor shall not cool: I will incense
Page
to deal with poison; I will possess
him with yellowness,
for the revolt of mine
is dangerous: that is my
true humor.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
Thou art the Mars of malecontents:
I second
thee; troop on.
[Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE IV
div2.stage: A room in DOCTOR CAIUS'S house.
Enter MISTRESS QUICKLY, SIMPLE, and RUGBY.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
What, John Rugby! I pray thee,
go to the casement,
and see if you can see my
master, Master Doctor
Caius, coming. If he
do, i' faith, and find any body
in the house,
here will be an old abusing of God's patience
and the king's English.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: I'll go watch.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Go; and we'll have a posset for't
soon at night,
in faith, at the latter end of a
sea-coal fire. [Exit Rugby.] An honest,
willing,
kind fellow, as ever servant shall come
in house
withal, and, I warrant you, no tell-tale
nor no breed-bate:
his worst fault is, that
he is given to prayer; he is
something peevish
that way: but nobody but has his
fault; but
let that pass. Peter Simple, you say your
name is?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Ay, for fault of a better.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: And Master Slender's your master?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Ay, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Does he not wear a great round
beard, like a
glover's paring-knife?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
No, forsooth: he hath but a little wee
face, with
a little yellow beard, a
Cain-colored beard.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: A softly-sprighted man, is he not?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
Ay, forsooth: but he is as tall a man
of his hands as
any is between this and his
head; he hath fought with
a warrener.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
How say you? O, I should remember
him: does
he not hold up his head, as it
were, and shut in his gait?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Yes, indeed, does he.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Well, heaven send Anne Page no
worse fortune!
Tell Master Parson Evans I
will do what I can for your
master: Anne is
a good girl, and I wish--
Re-enter RUGBY.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: Out, alas! here comes my master.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
We shall all be shent. Run in here,
good young
man; go into this closet: he will
not stay long. [Shuts Simple in the closet.]
What,
John Rugby! John! what, John, I say!
Go, John, go inquire
for my master; I doubt
he be not well, that he
comes not home.
[Singing] And down, down, adown-a, &c.
Enter DOCTOR CAIUS.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
Vat is you sing? I do not like des
toys. Pray
you, go and vetch me in my closet
un boitier vert,
a box, a green-a box: do intend
vat I speak? a
green-a box.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Ay, forsooth; I'll fetch it you.
[Aside] I am glad he went not in himself: if
he had found the
young man, he would have
been horn-mad.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
Fe, fe, fe, fe! ma foi, il fait fort
chaud. Je m'en vais a la
cour--la grande
affaire.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: Is it this, sir?

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
Oui; mette le au mon pocket: depeche,
quickly.
Vere is dat knave Rugby?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: What, John Rugby! John!

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: Here, sir!

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
You are John Rugby, and you are
Jack Rugby.
Come, take-a your rapier, and
come after my heel to
the court.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: 'Tis ready, sir, here in the porch.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
By my trot, I tarry too long. Od's
me! Qu'ai-j'oublie!
dere is some simples in
my closet, dat I vill not
for the varld I shall
leave behind.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Ay me, he'll find the young man
there, and be mad!

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
O diable, diable! vat is in my
closet?
Villain! larron! [Pulling Simple out.]
Rugby, my rapier!

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: Good master, be content.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.l: Wherefore shall I be content-a?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: The young man is an honest man.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
What shall de honest man do in my
closet? dere
is no honest man dat shall come
in my closet.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
I beseech you, be not so phlegmatic.
Hear the
truth of it: he came of an errand to
me from Parson
Hugh.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.l: Vell.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Ay, forsooth; to desire her to--

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: Peace, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
Peace-a your tongue. Speak-a your
tale.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
To desire this honest gentlewoman,
your maid,
to speak a good word to Mistress
Anne Page for my master
in the way of marriage.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
This is all, indeed, la! but I'll ne'er
put my finger
in the fire, and need not.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
Sir Hugh send-a you? Rugby, baille
me some
paper. Tarry you a little-a while.
[Writes.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
[Aside to Simple.] I am glad he is
so quiet: if he had been throughly
moved,
you should have heard him so loud and so
melancholy.
But notwithstanding, man, I'll do
you your
master what good I can: and the
very yea and the no is, the
French doctor, my
master,--I may call him my master,
look you,
for I keep his house; and I wash, wring, brew,
bake, scour, dress meat and drink, make the
beds, and
do all myself,--

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
[Aside to Quickly] 'Tis a great
charge to come under one body's
hand.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
[Aside to Simple] Are you avised
o' that? you shall find it a great
charge: and
to be up early and down late; but notwithstanding,
--to tell you in your ear; I would
have no words
of it,--my master himself is in
love with Mistress Anne
Page: but notwithstanding
that, I know Anne's mind,--that's
neither
here nor there.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
You jack'nape, give-a this letter to
Sir
Hugh; by gar, it is a shallenge: I will cut
his troat in de
park; and I will teach a scurvy
jack-a-nape priest to
meddle or make. You
may be gone; it is not good
you tarry here.
By gar, I will cut all his two stones; by
gar,
he shall not have a stone to throw at his dog.
[Exit Simple.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: Alas, he speaks but for his friend.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
It is no matter-a ver dat: do not
you tell-a me
dat I shall have Anne Page for
myself? By gar, I vill
kill de Jack priest; and
I have appointed mine host of de
Jarteer to
measure our weapon. By gar, I will myself
have Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Sir, the maid loves you, and all
shall be well.
We must give folks leave to
prate: what, the good-jer!

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
Rugby, come to the court with me.
By gar, if
I have not Anne Page, I shall turn
your head out of my
door. Follow my heels,
Rugby. [Exeunt Caius and Rugby.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
You shall have An fool's-head of
your own.
No, I know Anne's mind for that:
never a woman in Windsor
knows more of
Anne's mind than I do: nor can do
more than
I do with her, I thank heaven.

sp.speaker: Fent.
sp.p: [Within] Who's within there? ho!

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Who's there, I trow! Come near
the house, I
pray you.
Enter FENTON.

sp.speaker: Fent.
sp.p:
How now, good woman! how dost
thou?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
The better that it pleases your good
worship
to ask.

sp.speaker: Fent.
sp.p:
What news? how does pretty Mistress
Anne?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
In truth, sir, and she is pretty, and
honest, and
gentle; and one that is your
friend, I can tell you that by
the way; I praise
heaven for it.

sp.speaker: Fent.
sp.p:
Shall I do any good, thinkest thou?
shall I not
lose my suit?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Troth, sir, all is in his hands
above: but notwithstanding,
Master Fenton,
I'll be sworn on a book,
she loves you. Have
not your worship a wart above
your eye?

sp.speaker: Fent.
sp.l: Yes, marry, have I; what of that?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Well, thereby hangs a tale: good
faith, it is such
another Nan; but, I detest,
an honest maid as ever
broke bread: we had
an hour's talk of that wart. I
shall never laugh
but in that maid's company! But indeed
she
is given too much to allicholy and musing:
but for you--well, go to.

sp.speaker: Fent.
sp.p:
Well, I shall see her to-day. Hold,
there's money
for thee; let me have thy voice
in my behalf: if
thou seest her before me,
commend me.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Will I? i' faith, that we will; and I
will tell
your worship more of the wart the
next time we have
confidence; and of other
wooers.

sp.speaker: Fent.
sp.p:
Well, farewell; I am in great haste
now.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Farewell to your worship.
[Exit Fenton.] Truly, an honest
gentleman: but
Anne loves him not; for I know Anne's
mind
as well as another does. Out upon't! what
have I
forgot? [Exit.

div2.head: SCENE I
div2.stage: Enter MISTRESS PAGE, with a letter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
What, have I scaped love-letters
in the
holiday-time of my beauty, and am
I now a subject
for them? Let me see.
[Reads.

'Ask me no reason why I love you; for
though Love use Reason
for his physician, he
admits him not for his counsellor.
You are
not young, no more am I; go to then, there's
sympathy:
you are merry, so am I; ha, ha!
then there 's more sympathy:
you love sack,
and so do I; would you desire better sympathy?
Let it suffice thee, Mistress Page,--at
the least, if the love of
soldier can suffice,--
that I love thee. I will not say, pity me;
'tis
not a soldier-like phrase: but I say, love me.
By me,
Thine own true knight,
By day or night,
Or any kind of light,
With all his might
For thee to fight, JOHN FALSTAFF.'
What a Herod of Jewry is this! O wicked,
wicked world!
One that is well-nigh worn to
pieces with age
to show himself a young gallant!
What an unweighed
behavior hath this
Flemish drunkard picked--with
the devil's
name!--out of my conversation, that he dares
in this manner assay me? Why, he hath not
been thrice
in my company! What should I
say to him? I was then
frugal of my mirth:
Heaven forgive me! Why, I'll
exhibit a bill
in the parliament for the putting down
of men.
How shall I be revenged on him? for revenged
I
will be, as sure as his guts are made of
puddings.
Enter MISTRESS FORD.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Mistress Page! trust me, I was
going to your
house.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
And, trust me, I was coming to
you. You
look very ill.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Nay, I'll ne'er believe that; I
have to show
to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p: Faith, but you do, in my mind.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Well, I do then; yet I say I
could show
you to the contrary. O Mistress
Page, give me some
counsel!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p: What's the matter, woman?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
O woman, if it were not for
one trifling respect,
I could come to such
honor!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Hang the trifle, woman! take

the honor. 
What is it? dispense with trifles;

what is it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
If I would but go to hell for an
eternal
moment or so, I could be knighted.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
What? thou liest! Sir Alice
Ford! These
knights will hack; and so thou
shouldst not alter the article
of thy gentry.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
We burn daylight; here, read,
read;
perceive how I might be knighted. I
shall think the
worse of fat men, as long as I
have an eye to make difference
of men's liking;
and yet he would not swear;
praised
women's modesty; and gave such orderly and
well-behaved
reproof to all uncomeliness, that
I would have
sworn his disposition would have
gone to the truth of
his words; but they do
no more adhere and keep place
together than
the Hundredth Psalm to the tune of 'Green
Sleeves.'
What tempest, I trow, threw this
whale, with
so many tuns of oil in his belly,
ashore at Windsor?
How shall I be revenged
on him? I think the best way
were to entertain
him with hope, till the wicked fire
of lust
have melted him in his own grease. Did you
ever
hear the like?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Letter for letter, but that the
name of
Page and Ford differs! To thy great
comfort in this mystery
of ill opinions, here's
the twin-brother of thy letter:
but let thine
inherit first; for, I protest, mine never
shall.
I warrant he hath a thousand of these letters,
writ
with blank space for different names,--
sure, more,--and
these are of the second edition:
he will print them, out
of doubt; for
he cares not what he puts into the press,
when
he would put us two. I had rather be a giantess,
and lie under Mount Pelion. Well, I will
find you twenty
lascivious turtles ere one
chaste man.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Why, this is the very same;

the very hand, 
the very words.   What doth he

think of us?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Nay, I know not: it makes me
almost ready
to wrangle with mine own honesty.
I'll entertain
myself like one that I am
not acquainted withal; for,
sure, unless he
know some strain in me, that I know
not myself,
he would never have boarded me in this
fury.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
'Boarding,' call you it? I'll be
sure to keep
him above deck.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
So will I: if he come under
my hatches,
I'll never to sea again. Let's be
revenged on him: let's
appoint him a meeting;
give him a show of comfort in
his suit and lead
him on with a fine-baited delay, till
he
hath pawned his horses to mine host of
the Garter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Nay, I will consent to act any
villany against
him, that may not sully the
chariness of our honesty. O,
that my husband
saw this letter! it would give eternal
food to
his jealousy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Why, look where he comes;
and my good
man too: he's as far from jealousy
as I am from giving
him cause; and
that I hope is an unmeasurable
distance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p: You are the happier woman.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Let's consult together against
this greasy
knight. Come hither. [They retire. Enter FORD with PISTOL, and PAGE with NYM.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Well, I hope it be not so.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
Hope is a curtal dog in some affairs:
Sir John affects thy wife.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Why, sir, my wife is not young.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: He wooes both high and low, both rich and poor.
Both young and old, one with another, Ford;

He loves the
gallimaufry: Ford, perpend.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Love my wife!

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l:
With liver burning hot. Prevent,
or go thou,

Like Sir Actaeon he, with
Ringwood at thy heels:
O, odious is the name!

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: What name, sir?

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: The horn, I say. Farewell.
Take heed, have open eyes, for thieves do foot by night:
Take heed, ere summer comes or cuckoo-birds do sing.
Away, Sir Corporal Nym!
Believe it, Page; he speaks sense. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I will be patient; I will find
out this.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p:
And this is true; I like
not the humor of lying.
He hath wronged me
in some humors: I should have
borne the humored
letter to her; but I have a sword
and
it shall bite upon my necessity. He loves your
wife;
there's the short and the long. My name
is Corporal
Nym; I speak and I avouch; 'tis
true: my name is Nym
and Falstaff loves your
wife. Adieu. I love not the humor
of bread
and cheese, and there's the humor of it.
Adieu. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
'The humor of it,' quoth a'! here's
a fellow
frights English out of his wits.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: I will seek out Falstaff.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
I never heard such a drawling, affecting
rogue.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: If I do find it; well.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
I will not believe such a Cataian,
though the
priest o' the town commended him
for a true man.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: 'Twas a good sensible fellow: well.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l:
How now, Meg!
[Mrs. Page and Mrs. Ford come forward.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Whither go you, George?
Hark you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
How now, sweet Frank! why
art thou
melancholy?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I melancholy! I am not melancholy.
Get you home, go.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Faith, thou has some crotchets
in thy head.
Now, will you go, Mistress Page?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Have with you, You'll come to
dinner,
George. [Aside to Mrs. Ford] Look
who comes yonder; she shall be our
messenger
to this paltry knight.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
[Aside to Mrs. Page] Trust me,
I thought on her: she'll fit it.
Enter MISTRESS QUICKLY.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.l:
You are come to see my
daughter Anne?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Ay, forsooth; and, I pray, how does
good Mistress
Anne?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Go in with us and see: we
have an hour's
talk with you.
[Exeunt Mrs. Page, Mrs. Ford, and Mrs. Quickly.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: How now, Master Ford!

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
You heard what this knave told me,
did you not?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Yes: and you heard what the other
told me?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Do you think there is truth in them?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Hang 'em, slaves! I do not think the
knight
would offer it: but these that accuse
him in his intent
towards our wives are a yoke
of his discarded men; very
rogues, now they
be out of service.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Were they his men?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Marry, were they.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I like it never the better for that.
Does he lie at the Garter?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Ay, marry, does he. If he should intend
this voyage
towards my wife, I would
turn her loose to him;
and what he gets more
of her than sharp words, let it
lie on my head.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I do not misdoubt my wife; but I
would be
loath to turn them together. A man
may be too confident:
I would have nothing
lie on my head: I cannot
be thus satisfied.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Look where my ranting host of the
Garter
comes: there is either liquor in his
pate or money in his
purse when he looks so
merrily.
Enter HOST.
How now, mine
host!

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
How now, bully-rook! thou'rt a gentleman.
Cavaleiro-justice, I say!
Enter SHALLOW.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
I follow, mine host, I follow. Good
even
and twenty, good Master Page! Master
Page, will you go
with us? we have sport in
hand.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Tell him, cavaleiro-justice; tell him,
bully-rook.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Sir, there is a fray to be fought between
Sir
Hugh the Welsh priest and Caius the
French doctor.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Good mine host o' the Garter, a
word with you. [Drawing him aside.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: What sayest thou, my bully-rook?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
[To Page] Will you go with us to behold
it? My merry
host hath had the measuring
of their weapons; and, I
think, hath appointed
them contrary places; for, believe
me,
I hear the parson is no jester. Hark, I will
tell
you what our sport shall be.
[They converse apart.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Hast thou no suit against my knight,
my
guest-cavaleire?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
None, I protest: but I'll give you a
pottle of
burnt sack to give me recourse to
him and tell him
my name is Brook; only
for a jest.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
My hand, bully; thou shalt have
egress and
regress;--said I well?--and thy
name shall be Brook. It
is a merry knight.
Will you go, An-heires?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Have with you, mine host.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
I have heard the Frenchman hath
good skill
in his rapier.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Tut, sir, I could have told you more.
In these
times you stand on distance, your
passes, stoccadoes. and
I know not what:
'tis the heart, Master Page;
'tis here, 'tis here.
I have seen the time, with my long sword
I
would have made you four tall fellows skip
like
rats.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Here, boys, here, here shall we wag?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Have with you. I had rather hear
them scold
than fight.
[Exeunt Host, Shal., and Page.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Though Page be a secure fool, an
stands so
firmly on his wife's frailty, yet I
cannot put off my opinion
so easily: she was
in his company at Page's house;
and what
they made there, I know not. Well, I will look
further into't; and I have a disguise to sound
Falstaff. If
I find her honest, I lose not my
labor; if she be otherwise,
'tis labour well
bestowed. [Exit.

div2.head: SCENE II
div2.stage: A room in the Garter Inn.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I will not lend thee a penny.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
Why, then the world's mine oyster,
Which I
with sword will open.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Not a penny. I have been content, sir,
you
should lay my countenance to pawn: I
have grated upon
my good friends for three
reprieves for you and
your coach-fellow
Nym; or else you had looked through
the
grate, like a geminy of baboons. I am damned
in
hell for swearing to gentlemen my friends,
you were
good soldiers and tall fellows; and
when Mistress
Bridget lost the handle of her
fan, I took 't upon mine honor
thou hadst it not.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
Didst not thou share? hadst thou not fifteen
pence?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Reason, you rogue, reason: thinkest
thou I'll endanger
my soul gratis? At a word,
hang no more about
me, I am no gibbet for
you. Go. A short knife and a
throng! To your
manor of Pickt-hatch! Go. You'll not
bear a
letter for me, you rogue! you stand upon your
honor! Why, thou unconfinable baseness, it
is as much
as I can do to keep the terms of
my honor precise:
I, I, I myself sometimes,
leaving the fear of God on
the left hand and
hiding mine honor in my necessity, am
fain to
shuffle, to hedge and to lurch; and yet you,
rogue, will ensconce your rags, your cat-a-mountain
looks,
your red-lattice phrases, and
your bold-beating oaths,
under the shelter of
your honour! You
will not do it, you!

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
I do relent: what would thou more of man?
Enter ROBIN.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sir, here's a woman would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Let her approach.
Enter MISTRESS QUICKLY.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Give your worship good morrow.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Good morrow, good wife.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Not so, an 't please your worship.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Good maid, then.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
I'll be sworn,
As my mother was, the first hour I was born.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I do believe the swearer. What with me?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Shall I vouchsafe your worship a
word or
two?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Two thousand, fair woman: and I'll
vouchsafe
thee the hearing.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
There is one Mistress Ford, sir:--
I pray come a
little nearer this ways:--I myself
dwell with Master Doctor
Caius,--

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Well, on: Mistress Ford, you say,--

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Your worship says very true: I
pray your worship,
come a little nearer this
ways.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I warrant thee, nobody hears; mine
own
people, mine own people.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Are they so? God bless them and
make
them his servants!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Well, Mistress Ford; what of her?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Why, sir, she's a good creature.
Lord, Lord!
your worship's a wanton! Well,
heaven forgive you
and all of us, I pray!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Mistress Ford; come, Mistress Ford,--

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Marry, this is the short and the
long of it; you
have brought her into such a
canaries as 'tis wonderful.
The best courtier
of them all, when the court lay
at Windsor,
could never have brought her to such a canary.
Yet there has been knights, and lords,
and gentlemen,
with their coaches, I warrant
you, coach after
coach, letter after letter, gift
after gift; smelling so sweetly,
all musk, and
so rushling, I warrant you, in silk
and gold;
and in such alligant terms; and in such wine
and sugar of the best and the fairest, that
would have
won any woman's heart; and I
warrant you, they could
never get an eye-wink
of her: I had myself twenty
angels given me
this morning; but I defy all angels, in
any
such sort, as they say, but in the way of honesty:
and,
I warrant you, they could never
get her so much as sip
on a cup with the
proudest of them all: and yet there has
been
earls, nay, which is more, pensioners; but, I
warrant you, all is one with her.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
But what says she to me? be brief,
my good
she-Mercury.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Marry, she hath received your letter,
for the
which she thanks you a thousand
times; and she gives
you to notify that her
husband will be absence from his
house between
ten and eleven.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Ten and eleven?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Ay, forsooth; and then you may
come and see the
picture, she says, that you
wot of: Master Ford, her husband,
will be
from home. Alas! the sweet woman leads
an
ill life with him: he's a very jealousy man:
she leads
a very frampold life with him, good
heart.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Ten and eleven.
Woman, commend
me to her; I will not fail her.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Why, you say well. But I have another
messenger
to your worship. Mistress
Page hath her hearty
commendations to you
too: and let me tell you in your
ear, she's as
fartuous a civil modest wife, and one, I
tell
you, that will not miss you morning nor evening
prayer, as any is in Windsor, whoe'er be
the other: and
she bade me tell your worship
that her husband is seldom
from home; but
she hopes there will come a time.
I never
knew a woman so dote upon a man: surely
I
think you have charms, la; yes, in truth.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Not I, I assure thee: setting the attraction
of my
good parts aside I have no
other charms.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: Blessing on your heart for't!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
But, I pray thee, tell me this: has
Ford's wife and
Page's wife acquainted each
other how they love me?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
That were a jest indeed! they have
not so little
grace, I hope: that were a trick
indeed! but Mistress Page
would desire you to
send her your little page, of all loves:
her
husband has a marvellous infection to the
little page;
and truly Master Page is an honest
man. Never a wife in
Windsor leads a better
life than she does: do what she
will, say what
she will, take all, pay all, go to bed when
she
list, rise when she list, all is as she will: and
truly she
deserves it; for if there be a kind
woman in Windsor, she
is one. You must
send her your page; no remedy.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Why, I will.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Nay, but do so, then: and, look
you, he may
come and go between you both;
and in any case have
a nay-word, that you
may know one another's mind,
and the boy
never need to understand any thing; for
'tis
not good that children should know any wickedness:
old folks, you know, have discretion,
as they say, and
know the world.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Fare thee well: commend me to them
both:
there's my purse; I am yet thy debtor
Boy, go along
with this woman.
[Exeunt Mistress Quickly and Robin.] This news
distracts me!

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: This punk is one of Cupid's carriers:
'Clap on more sails; pursue; up with your fights:
Give fire: she is my prize, or ocean whelm them all! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Sayest thou so, old Jack? go thy
ways; I'll make
more of thy old body than I
have done. Will they yet
look after thee? Wilt
thou, after the expense of so much
money,
be now a gainer? Good body, I thank thee.
Let
them say 'tis grossly done; so it be fairly
done, no
matter.
Enter BARDOLPH.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p:
Sir John, there's one Master Brook
below would
fain speak with you, and be acquainted
with you; and
hath sent your worship
a morning's draught of sack.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Brook is his name?

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: Ay, sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Call him in. [Exit Bardolph.] Such
Brooks are welcome to me,
that o'erflow such
liquor. Ah, ha! Mistress Ford and Mistress
Page, have I encompassed you? go to; via!
Re-enter BARDOLPH, with FORD disguised.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Bless you, sir!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: And you, sir! Would you speak with me?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I make bold to press with so little
preparation
upon you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
You're welcome. What's your will?
Give us leave,
drawer. [Exit Bardolph.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Sir, I am a gentleman that have
spent much:
my name is Brook.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Good Master Brook, I desire more
acquaintance
of you.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Good Sir John, I sue for yours: not
to charge
you; for I must let you understand
I think myself in
better plight for a lender
than you are: the which hath
something emboldened
me to this unseasoned intrusion;
for
they say, if money go before, all ways do lie
open.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Money is a good soldier, sir, and will on.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Troth, and I have a bag of money
here troubles
me: if you will help to bear it,
Sir John, take all,
or half, for easing me of
the carriage.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Sir, I know not how I may deserve to
be your
porter.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I will tell you, sir, if you will give
me the
hearing.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Speak, good Master Brook: I shall
be glad to
be your servant.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Sir, I hear you are a scholar,--I will
be brief
with you,--and you have been a man
long known to me,
though I had never so good
means, as desire, to make myself
acquainted
with you. I shall discover a thing to
you,
wherein I must very much lay open mine own
imperfection:
but good Sir John, as you have
one eye upon
my follies, as you hear them unfolded,
turn another
into the register of your
own; that I may pass with a
reproof the
easier, sith you yourself know how easy it
is
to be such an offender.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Very well, sir; proceed.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
There is a gentlewoman in this
town; her
husband's name is Ford.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Well, sir.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I have long loved her, and, I protest
to you, bestowed
much on her; followed her
with a doting observance;
engrossed opportunities
to meet her; fee'd every
slight occasion
that could but niggardly give me
sight
of her; not only bought many presents to give
her,
but have given largely to many to know
what she
would have given; briefly, I have
pursued her as love
hath pursued me; which
hath been on the wing of all
occasions. But
whatsoever I have merited, either in my
mind
or in my means, meed, I am sure, I have received
none; unless experience be a jewel that
I have purchased
at an infinite rate, and that
hath taught me to say
this:
sp.l: 'Love like a shadow flies when substance love pursues;
Pursuing that that flies, and flying what pursues.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Have you received no promise of satisfaction
at
her hands?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Have you importuned her to such a purpose?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Of what quality was your love, then?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Like a fair house built on another
man's ground;
so that I have lost my edifice
by mistaking the place
where I erected it.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
To what purpose have you unfolded
this to me?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
When I have told you that, I have
told you all.
Some say, that though she appear
honest to me, yet in
other places she enlargeth
her mirth so far that there
is shrewd
construction made of her. Now, Sir John, here
is the heart of my purpose: you are a gentleman
of excellent
breeding, admirable discourse,
of great admittance,
authentic in your
place and person, generally
allowed for your
many war-like, court-like, and learned
preparations.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: O, sir!

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Believe it, for you know it. There
is money;
spend it, spend it; spend more;
spend all I have; only
give me so much of
your time in exchange of it, as to lay
an amiable
siege to the honesty of this Ford's wife:
use
your art of wooing; win her to consent
to you: if any
man may, you may as soon
as any.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Would it apply well to the vehemency
of your
affection, that I should win what you
would enjoy? Methinks
you prescribe by yourself
very preposterously.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
O, understand my drift. She dwells
so securely
on the excellency of her honor,
that the folly of my soul
dares not present itself:
she is too bright to be looked
against.
Now, could I come to her with any detection
in my hand, my desires had instance and argument
to
commend themselves: I could drive
her then from the
ward of her purity, her reputation,
her marriage-vow,
and a thousand
other her defences, which now are too
too
strongly embattled against me. What say you
to't,
Sir John?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Master Brook, I will first make bold
with your
money; next, give me your hand;
and last, as I am a
gentleman, you shall, if
you will, enjoy Ford's wife.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: O good sir!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I say you shall.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Want no money, Sir John; you shall
want none.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Want no Mistress Ford, Master
Brook: you shall
want none. I shall be with
her, I may tell you, by her
own appointment;
even as you came in to me, her assistant
or
go-between parted from me: I say I shall be
with her between ten and eleven; for at that
time the
jealous rascally knave her husband
will be forth. Come
you to me at night; you
shall know how I speed.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I am blest in your acquaintance. Do
you know
Ford, sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Hang him, poor cuckoldly knave! I
know
him not: yet I wrong him to call him
poor; they say
the jealous wittolly knave hath
masses of money; for
the which his wife seems
to me well-favored. I will use
her as the key
of the cuckoldly rogue's coffer; and there's
my harvest-home.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I would you knew Ford, sir, that
you might avoid
him if you saw him.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Hang him, mechanical salt-butter
rogue! I will
stare him out of his wits; I will
awe him with my cudgel:
it shall hang like a
meteor o'er the cuckold's horns.
Master
Brook, thou shalt know I will predominate
over
the peasant and thou shalt lie with his
wife. Come
to me soon at night. Ford's a
knave, and I will aggravate
his style; thou,
Master Brook, shalt know him for
knave and
cuckold. Come to me soon at night. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
What a damned Epicurean rascal is
this! My
heart is ready to crack with impatience.
Who says this
is improvident jealousy?
my wife hath sent to him; the
hour is
fixed; the match is made. Would any man
have
thought this? See the hell of having a
false woman! My
bed shall be abused, my
coffers ransacked, my reputation
gnawn at;
and I shall not only receive this villanous
wrong, but stand under the adoption of abominable
terms, and by him that does me this
wrong. Terms!
names! Amaimon sounds
well; Lucifer, well; Barbason, well; yet they
are devils' additions, the names of fiends:
but
Cuckold! Wittol!--Cuckold! the devil himself
hath not such a name. Page is an ass, a
secure ass: he
will trust his wife: he will not
be jealous. I will rather
trust a Fleming with
my butter, Parson Hugh the Welshman
with
my cheese, an Irishman with my aqua-vitae
bottle, or a thief to walk my ambling gelding,
than
my wife with herself: then she plots,
then she ruminates, then she devises; and
what they think in their
hearts they may effect,
they will break their hearts but
they will
effect. God be praised for my jealousy!
Eleven o'clock the hour. I will prevent this,
detect
my wife, be revenged on Falstaff, and
laugh at Page. I
will about it; better three
hours too soon than a minute
too late. Fie, fie,
fie! cuckold! cuckold! cuckold!
[Exit.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Jack Rugby!

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Vat is de clock, Jack?

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p:
'Tis past the hour, sir, that Sir Hugh
promised
to meet.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
By gar, he has save his soul, dat he
is no come;
he has pray his Pible well, dat he
is no come: by gar,
Jack Rugby, he is dead
already, if he be come.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p:
He is wise, sir; he knew your worship
would
kill him, if he came.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
By gar, de herring is no dead so as
I vill kill
him. Take your rapier, Jack; I vill
tell you how I vill
kill him.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p: Alas, sir, I cannot fence.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Villany, take your rapier.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p:
Forbear; here's company.
Enter HOST, SHALLOW, SLENDER, and PAGE.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Bless thee, bully doctor!

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Save you, Master Doctor Caius!

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Now, good master doctor!

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Give you good morrow, sir.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
Vat be all you, one, two, tree, four,
come for?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
To see thee fight, to see thee foin, to
see thee
traverse; to see thee here, to see thee
there; to see thee
pass thy punto, thy stock,
thy reverse, thy distance, thy
montant. Is he
dead, my Ethiopian? is he dead, my Francisco?
ha, bully! What says my AEsculapius?
my Galen? my
heart of elder? ha! is he dead,
bully stale? is he dead?

sp.speaker: Caius.
Host.
sp.p:
Thou art a Castalion-King-Urinal.
Hector of
Greece, my boy!

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
I pray you, bear vitness that me
have stay
six or seven, two, tree hours for him,
and he is no
come.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
He is the wiser man, master doctor:
he is a curer of
souls, and you a curer of
bodies; if you should fight, you
go against the
hair of your professions. Is it not true,
Master
Page?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Master Shallow, you have yourself
been a
great fighter, though now a man of
peace.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Bodykins, Master Page, though I now
be old and
of the peace, if I see a sword out,
my finger itches to
make one. Though we are
justices and doctors and
churchmen, Master
Page, we have some salt of our youth
in us;
we are the sons of women, Master

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: 'Tis true, Master Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
It will be found so, Master Page.
Master Doctor Caius,
I am come to fetch you
home. I am sworn of the peace:
you have
showed yourself a wise physician, and Sir
Hugh hath shown himself a wise and patient
churchman.
You must go with me, master
doctor.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Pardon, guest-justice. A word, Mounseur
Mockwater.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.l: Mock-vater! vat is dat?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Mock-water, in our English tongue,
is valor,
bully.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
By gar, den, I have as mush mockvater
as de
Englishman. Scurvy jack-dog
priest! by gar, me vill
cut his ears.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
He will clapper-claw thee tightly,
bully.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.l: Clapper-de-claw! vat is dat?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: That is, he will make thee amends.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
By gar, me do look he shall clapper-de-claw
me; for, by gar, me vill have it.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
And I will provoke him to't, or let
him wag.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.l: Me tank you for dat.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
And, moreover, bully,--but first,
master guest,
and Master Page, and eke Cavaleiro
Slender, go you through
the town to
Frogmore. [Aside to them.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Sir Hugh is there, is he?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
He is there: see what humor he is
in; and I will
bring the doctor about by the
fields. Will it do well?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: We will do it.

sp.speaker: Page., Shal., and Slen.
sp.p:
Adieu, good master doctor.
[Exeunt Page, Shal., and Slen.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
By gar, me vill kill de priest; for
he speak for a
jack-an-ape to Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Let him die; sheathe thy impatience,
throw cold
water on thy choler: go about the
fields with me
through Frogmore: I will bring
thee where Mistress Anne
Page is, at a farm-house
a-feasting; and thou shalt woo
her.
Cried I aim? said I well?

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
By gar, me dank you vor dat: by
gar, I love
you; and I shall procure-a you de
good guest, de earl,
de knight, de lords, de
gentlemen, my patients.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
For the which I will be thy adversary
toward
Anne Page. Said I well?

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.l: By gar, 'tis good; veil said.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Let us wag, then.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.l:
Come at my heels, Jack Rugby.
[Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE I
div2.stage: Enter SIR HUGH EVANS and SIMPLE.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
I pray you now, good Master Slender's
serving-man,
and friend Simple by your
name, which way have
you looked for Master
Caius, that calls himself doctor
of physic?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
Marry, sir, the pittie-ward, the park-ward,
every way; old Windsor way, and
every way but the
town way.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
I most fehemently desire you you
will also
look that way.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l:
I will, sir.
[Exit.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
'Pless my soul, how full of chollors
I am, and
trempling of mind! I shall be
glad if he have deceived
me. How melancholies
I am! I will knog his urinals about
his knave's costard when I have good opportunities
for the ork. 'Pless my soul!
[Sings.
sp.l:
To shallow rivers, to whose
falls
Melodious birds sings madrigals;

There will we make
our peds of roses,
And a thousand fragrant posies.
To shallow--
sp.p:
Mercy on me! I have a great dispositions to
cry. [Sings.
sp.l: Melodious birds sing madrigals--
When as I sat in Pabylon--
And a thousand vagram posies.

To shallow, &c.
Re-enter SIMPLE.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
Yonder he is coming, this way, Sir
Hugh.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
He's welcome.
[Sings.
sp.l: To shallow rivers, to whose falls--
Heaven prosper the right! What weapons is he?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
No weapons, sir. There comes my
master, Master
Shallow, and another gentle-
man, from Frogmore, over
the stile, this way.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Pray you, give me my gown; or
else keep it
in your arms.
Enter PAGE, SHALLOW, and SLENDER.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
How now, master Parson! Good
morrow, good
Sir Hugh. Keep a gamester
from the dice, and a good
student from his
book, and it is wonderful.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: [Aside] Ah, sweet Anne Page!

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: 'Save you, good Sir Hugh!

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
'Pless you from his mercy sake, all
of you

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
What, the sword and the word!
do
you study them both, master parson?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
And youthful still! in your doublet
and hose
this raw rheumatic day!

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.l: There is reasons and causes for it.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
We are come to you to do a good
office, master
parson.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.l: Fery well: what is it?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Yonder is a most reverend gentleman,
who,
belike having received wrong by
some person, is at
most odds with his own
gravity and patience that ever
you saw.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
I have lived fourscore years and upward;

I 
never heard a man of his place, gravity

 and learning, 
so wide of his own respect.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.l: What is he?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
I think you know him; Master Doctor
Caius, the
renowned French physician. 61

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Got's will, and his passion of my
heart! I had
as lief you would tell me of a
mess of porridge.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
He has no more knowledge in Hibocrates
and
Galen, and he is a knave besides;
a cowardly knave as
you would desires
to be acquainted withal.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
I warrant you, he's the man should
fight with
him.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: [Aside] O sweet Anne Page!

sp.speaker: Shal.
Page.
sp.p:
Nay, good master parson, keep in
your weapon.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: So do you, good master doctor.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Disarm them, and let them question:
let them
keep their limbs whole and hack our
English.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
I pray you, let-a me speak a word
with your
ear. Vherefore vill you not meet-
a me?

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
[Aside to Caius] Pray you, use
your patience: in good time.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
By gar, you are de coward, de Jack
dog, John
ape.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Pray you, let us
not be laughing-stocks to other
men's humours;
I desire you in friendship and will one
way
or other make you amends. [Aloud] I will
knog your urinals
about your knave's cogs-
comb for missing your meetings and appointments.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
Diable! Jack Rugby,--mine host
de Jarteer,--have I
not stay for him to kill
him? have I not, at de place I did
appoint?

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
As I am a Christians soul now,
look you,
this is the place appointed: I'll be
judgement by mine
host of the Garter.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Peace, I say, Gallia and Gaul,

French and Welsh,
soul-curer and body-curer!

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.l: Ay, dat is very good; excellent.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Peace, I say! hear mine host of the
Garter.
Am I politic? am I subtle? am I
a Machiavel?
Shall I lose my doctor? no;
he gives me the potions
and the motions.
Shall I lose my parson, my priest,
my Sir
Hugh? no: he gives me the proverbs and the
no-verbs. Give me thy hand, terrestrial; so.
Give me thy hand, celestial; so. Boys of
art,
I have deceived you both; I have directed you
to
wrong places: your hearts are mighty, your
skins are
whole, and let burnt sack be the issue.
Come, lay their
swords to pawn. Follow
me, lads of peace; follow, follow,
follow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Trust me, a mad host. Follow, gentlemen,
follow.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l:
O sweet Anne Page!
Exeunt Shal., Slen., Page, and Host.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
Ha, do I perceive dat? have you
make-a de sot
of us, ha, ha?

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
This is well; he has made us his
vlouting-stog.
I desire you that we may be
friends; and let us knog our
prains together
to be revenge on this same scall, scurvy,
cogging
companion, the host of the Garter.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
By gar, with all my heart. He
promise to bring
me where is Anne Page; by
gar, he deceive me too.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Well, I will smite his noddles.
Pray you, follow.
[Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE II
div2.stage: A street. Enter MISTRESS PAGE and ROBIN.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Nay, keep your way, little gallant;
you
were wont to be a follower, but now
you are a leader.
Whether had you rather
lead mine eyes, or eye your master's
heels?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
I had rather, forsooth, go before you
like a man
than follow him like a dwarf.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
O, you are a flattering boy:
now I see you'll be a courtier.
Enter FORD.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Well met, Mistress Page. Whither
go you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Truly, sir, to see your wife. Is
she at home?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Ay; and as idle as she may hang
together, for want
of company. I think, if
your husbands were dead, you
two would
marry.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Be sure of that,--two other
husbands.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Where had you this pretty weather-cock?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
I cannot tell what the dickens
his name is my
husband had him of. What
do you call your knight's name, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Sir John Falstaff.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Sir John Falstaff!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
He, he; I can never hit on's
name. There is such a
league between my
good man and he! Is your wife at home
indeed?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Indeed she is.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
By your leave, sir: I am sick
till I see her.
[Exeunt Mrs. Page and Robin.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Has Page any brains? hath he any
eyes? hath he
any thinking? Sure, they sleep;
he hath no use of them.
Why, this boy will
carry a letter twenty mile, as easy as
a cannon
will shoot point-blank twelve score. He pieces
out his wife's inclination; he gives her folly
motion
and advantage: and now she's going to
my wife, and Falstaff's
boy with her. A man
may hear this shower sing
in the wind. And
Falstaff's boy with her! Good plots,
they
are laid; and our revolted wives share damnation
together. Well; I will take him,
then torture my wife,
pluck the borrowed veil
of modesty from the so seeming
Mistress
Page, divulge Page himself for a secure and
wilful Actaeon; and to these violent proceedings
all my
neighbours shall cry aim.
[Clock heard.] The clock
gives me my cue,
and my assurance bids me
search: there I shall find Falstaff:
I shall be
rather praised for this than mocked; for
it is
as positive as the earth is firm that Falstaff is
there: I will go.
Enter PAGE, SHALLOW, SLENDER, HOST, SIR HUGH EVANS, CAIUS, and RUGBY.

sp.speaker: Shal., Page, &c.
sp.p: Well met, Master Ford.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Trust me a good knot: I have good
cheer at
home; and I pray you all go with me.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I must excuse myself, Master Ford.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
And so must I, sir:
we have appointed
to dine with Mistress Anne,
and I
would not break with her for more money
than I'll speak of.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
We have lingered about a match between
Anne
Page and my cousin Slender, and
this day we shall have
our answer.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I hope I have your good will, father
Page.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
You have, Master Slender; I stand
wholly for you:
but my wife, master doctor,
is for you altogether.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
Ay, be-gar; and de maid is love-a
me: my nursh-a-Quickly
tell me so mush.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
What say you to young Master Fenton?
he capers,
he dances, he has eyes of
youth, he writes verses, he
speaks holiday, he
smells April and May: he will carry't,
he
will carry't; 'tis in his buttons; he will
carry't.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Not by my consent, I promise you.
The gentleman
is of no having: he kept company
with the wild
prince and Poins; he is
of too high a region; he knows
too much. No,
he shall not knit a knot in his fortunes
with
the finger of my substance: if he takes her, let
him
take her simply; the wealth I have waits
on my consent,
and my consent goes not that
way.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I beseech you heartily, some of you
go home
with me to dinner: besides your
cheer, you shall have
sport; I will show you a
monster. Master doctor, you shall
go; so
shall you, Master Page; and you, Sir Hugh.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Well, fare you well:
we shall have
the freer wooing at Master Page's.
[Exeunt Shal. and Slen.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.l:
Go home, John Rugby: I come anon.
[Exit Rugby.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Farewell, my hearts: I will to my
honest knight
Falstaff, and drink canary with
him.
[Exit.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I think I shall drink in
pipe-wine first with
him: I'll make him dance.
Will you go, gentles?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l:
Have with you to see this monster.
[Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE III
div2.stage: Enter MISTRESS FORD and MISTRESS PAGE.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p: What, John! What, Robert!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.l: Quickly, quickly! Is the buck-basket--

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p: I warrant. What, Robin, I say! Enter SERVANTS with a basket.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.l: Come, come, come.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p: Here, set it down.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Give your men the charge; we
must be brief.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Marry, as I told you before,
John and Robert,
be ready here hard by in
the brew-house: and when I suddenly
call
you, come forth, and without any pause or
staggering take this basket on your shoulders:
that done,
trudge with it in all haste, and
carry it among the whitsters
in Datchet-mead,
and there empty it in the muddy
ditch close
by the Thames side.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.l: You will do it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
I ha' told them over and over;
they lack no direction.
Be gone, and come
when you are called.
[Exeunt Servants.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.l:
Here comes little Robin.
Enter ROBIN.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
How now, my eyas-musket!
what news with you?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
My master, Sir John, is come in at
your back-door,
Mistress Ford, and requests
your company.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
You little Jack-a-Lent, have
you been true to us?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
Ay, I'll be sworn. My master knows
not of your
being here and hath threatened to
put me into everlasting
liberty if I tell you of
it; for he swears he'll turn
me away.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Thou'rt a good boy: this secrecy
of thine
shall be a tailor to thee and
shall make thee a new doublet
and hose. I'll
go hide me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Do so. Go tell thy master I
am alone. [Exit Robin. Mistress
Page, remember
you your cue.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
I warrant thee; if I do not act
it, hiss me.
[Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Go to, then: we'll use this
unwholesome
humidity, this gross watery
pumpion; we'll teach him
to know turtles
from jays.
Enter FALSTAFF.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Have I caught thee, my heavenly
jewel? Why,
now let me die, for I have lived
long enough: this is the
period of my ambition:
O this blessed hour!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p: O sweet Sir John!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Mistress Ford, I cannot cog, I cannot
prate, Mistress
Ford. Now shall I sin in my
wish: I would thy husband
were dead: I'll
speak it before the best lord; I would
make
thee my lady.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
I your lady, Sir John! alas, I
should be a
pitiful lady!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Let the court of France show me
such another.
I see how thine eye would emulate
the diamond: thou
hast the right arched
beauty of the brow that becomes
the ship-tire,
the tire-valiant, or any tire of Venetian
admittance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
A plain kerchief, Sir John:
my brows become nothing else; nor that well
neither.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
By the Lord. thou art a traitor to say
so: thou wouldst make
an absolute courtier;
and the firm fixture of thy foot
would give an
excellent motion to thy gait in a semi-circled
farthingale. I see what thou wert, if Fortune
thy
foe were not, Nature thy friend. Come,
thou canst not
hide it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Believe me, there's no such
thing in me.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
What made me love thee? let that
persuade
thee there's something extraordinary
in thee. Come, I
cannot cog and cay thou art
this and that, like a many
of these lisping
hawthorn-buds, that come like women
in men's
apparel, and smell like Bucklersbury in simple
time; I cannot: but I love thee; none but
thee; and
thou deserves it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Do not betray me, sir. I fear
you love Mistress Page.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Thou mightst as well say I love to
walk by the
Counter-gate, which is as hateful
to me as the reek of
a lime-kiln.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
Fal.
sp.p: Keep in that mind; I'll deserve it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
Rob.
sp.p:
[Within] Mistress Ford, Mistress
Ford! here's Mistress Page at
the door sweating
and blowing and looking wildly,
and
would needs speak with you presently.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
She shall not see me: I will ensconce
me behind
the arras.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Pray you, do so: she's a very
tattling woman.
[Falstaff hides himself.
Re-enter MISTRESS PAGE and ROBIN.
What's the matter? how now!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
O Mistress Ford, what have
you done?
You're shamed, you're over-
thrown, you're undone for ever!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p: What's the matter, good Mistress Page?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
O well-a-day, Mistress Ford!
having an honest man
to your husband, to
give him such cause of suspicion!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p: What cause of suspicion?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
What cause of suspicion! Out
upon you!
how am I mistook in you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p: Why, alas, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Your husband's coming hither,
woman,
with all the officers in Windsor, to
search for a gentleman
that he says is here
now in the house by your
consent, to take an
ill advantage of his absence: you are
undone.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p: 'Tis not so, I hope.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Pray heaven it be not so, that
you have such
a man here! but 'tis most certain
your husband's coming,
with half Windsor
at his heels, to search for such
a one. I
come before to tell you. If you know yourself
clear, why, I am glad of it; but if you
have a friend here,
convey, convey him out.
Be not amazed; call all your
senses to you;
defend your reputation, or bid farewell to
your good life for ever.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
What shall I do? There is a
gentleman my
dear friend; and I fear not
mine own shame so much
as his peril: I had
rather than a thousand pound he were
out of
the house.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
For shame! never stand 'you
had rather' and
'you had rather:' your husband's
here at hand; bethink
you of some
conveyance; in the house you cannot hide
him.
O, how have you deceived me! Look, here is
a
basket: if he be of any reasonable stature,
he may creep
in here; and throw foul linen
upon him, as if it were
going to bucking: or--
it is whiting time--send him by
your two men
to Datchet-mead.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
He's too big to go in there.
What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Let me see't, let
me see't, O, let me see't!
I'll in, I'll in.
sp.l: Follow your friend's counsel. I'll in.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
What, Sir John Falstaff! Are
these your letters,
knight?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l:
I love thee. Help me away. Let me
creep in
here. I'll never--
[Gets into the basket; they cover him with foul linen.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Help to cover your master,
boy. Call
your men, Mistress Ford. You
dissembling knight!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
What, John! Robert! John!
[Exit Robin.
Re-enter Servants.
Go take up these
clothes here quickly. Where's
the cowl-staff? look,
how you drumble!
Carry them to the laundress in Datchet-mead;
quickly, come.
Enter FORD, PAGE, CAIUS, and SIR HUGH EVANS.

sp.speaker: Ford.
Serv.
sp.p: To the laundress, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Why, what have you to do
whither they
bear it? You were best meddle
with buck-washing.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Buck! I would I could wash myself
of the buck!
Buck, buck, buck! Ay,
buck; I warrant you, buck;
and of the season
too, it shall appear.
[Exeunt Servants with the basket.]
Gentlemen, I have dreamed tonight;
I'll tell you my
dream. Here, here,
here be my keys: ascend my
chambers;
search, seek, find out: I'll warrant we'll
unkennel
the fox. Let me stop this way first. [Locking the door.]
So, now
uncape.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Good Master Ford, be contented;
you wrong yourself too much.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
True, Master Page. Up, gentlemen;
you shall see sport anon:
follow me.
gentlemen.
[Exit.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
This is fery fantastical humours
and jealousies.

sp.speaker: Caius.
Page.
sp.p:
Nay, follow him, gentlemen; see
the issue of
his search.
[Exeunt Page, Caius and Evans.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Is there not a double excellency
in this?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
I know not which pleases me
better,
that my husband is deceived, or Sir
John.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
What a taking was he in when
your
husband asked who was in the basket!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
I am half afraid he will have
need of
washing; so throwing him into the
water will do him
a benefit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Hang him, dishonest rascal! I
would all
of the same strain were in the same
distress.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
I think my husband hath some
special
suspicion of Falstaff's being here; for
I never saw him so
gross in his jealousy till
now.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
I will lay a plot to try that;
and we will
yet have more tricks with Falstaff:
his dissolute disease
will scarce obey
this medicine.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Shall we send that foolish carrion,
Mistress
Quickly, to him, and excuse his
