throwing ipto the water;
and give him another
hope, to betray him to another
punishment?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
We will do it: let him be sent
for to-morrow,
eight o'clock, to have amends.
Re-enter FORD, PAGE, CAIUS, and SIR HUGH EVANS.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I cannot find him: may be the knave
bragged
of that he could not compass.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p: Heard you that?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p: You use me well, Master Ford, do you?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Ay, I do so.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Heaven make you better than
sour thoughts!

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Amen!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
You do yourself mighty wrong,
Master Ford.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Ay, ay; I must bear it.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
If there be any pody in the house
and in the chambers,
and in the coffers, and
in the presses, heaven forgive
my sins at
the day of judgement!

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
By gar, nor I too: there is no
bodies.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Fie, fie, Master Ford! are you not
ashamed? What spirit,
what devil suggests
this imagination? I would not ha'
your distemper
in this kind for the wealth of Windsor
Castle.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
'Tis my fault, Master Page: I suffer
for it.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
You suffer for a pad conscience:
your wife is
as honest a 'omans as I will desires
among five thousand,
and five hundred
too.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.l: By gar, I see 'tis an honest woman.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Well, I promised you a dinner.

Come, come back 
in the Park: I pray you,

pardon me; I will hereafter make 
known to

you why I have done this.   Come, wife;

come, 
Mistress Page. I pray you pardon me;

pray heartily, pardon me.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Let's go in, gentlemen; but, trust
me, we'll mock
him. I do invite you to-morrow
morning to my house
to breakfast: after,
we'll a-birding together; I have a fine
hawk
for the bush. Shall it be so?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
If there is one, I shall make two in
the company.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
If dere be one or two, I shall make-
a the turd.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Pray you, go, Master Page.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
I pray you now, remembrance to-morrow
on the
lousy knave, mine host.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
Dat is good; by gar, with all my
heart!

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
A lousy knave, to have his gibes
and his
mockeries!
[Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fent.
sp.l: I see I cannot get thy father's love;
Therefore no more turn me to him, sweet Nan.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Alas, how then?

sp.speaker: Fent.
sp.l: Why, thou must be thyself.
He doth object I am too great of birth;
And that, my state being gall'd with my expense,
I seek to heal it only by his wealth:
Besides these, other bars he lays before me,
My riots past, my wild societies;
And tells me 'tis a thing impossible
I should love thee but as a property.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: May be he tells you true.

sp.speaker: Fent.
sp.l: No, heaven so speed me in my time to come!
Albeit I will confess thy father's wealth
Was the first motive that I woo'd thee, Anne:
Yet, wooing thee, I found thee of more value
Than stamps in gold or sums in sealed bags;
And 'tis the very riches of thyself
That now I aim at.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Gentle Master Fenton,
Yet seek my father's love; still seek it, sir:
If opportunity and humblest suit

Cannot attain it, why, then,--hark you hither!
[They converse apart.
Enter SHALLOW, SLENDER, and MISTRESS QUICKLY.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Break their talk, Mistress Quickly:
my kinsman shall speak for himself.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I'll make a shaft or a bolt on't:
'slid, 'tis but venturing.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Be not dismayed.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
No, she shall not dismay me:
I care
not for that, but that I am afeard.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Hark ye; Master Slender would
speak a word with you.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: I come to him. Aside
This is my father's choice.
O, what a world of vile ill-favour'd faults
Looks handsome in three hundred pounds ayear!

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
And how does good Master Fenton?
Pray you, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
She's coming; to her, coz.
O boy,
thou hadst a father!

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I had a father, Mistress Anne; my
uncle can tell you good
jests of him. Pray
you, uncle, tell Mistress Anne the jest, how
my father stole two geese out of a pen, good
uncle.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Mistress Anne, my cousin loves you.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Ay, that I do: as well as I love any
woman in
Gloucestershire.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: He will maintain you like a gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Ay, that I will, come cut and long-tail,
under the
degree of a squire.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
He will make you a hundred and
fifty pounds
jointure.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p:
Good Master Shallow, let him woo
for
himself.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Marry, I thank you for it; I thank
you for
that good comfort. She calls you,
coz: I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Now, Master Slender,--

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: Now, good Mistress Anne,--

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: What is your will?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
My will! 'od's heartlings, that's a
pretty
jest indeed! I ne'er made my will yet,
I thank heaven;
I am not such a sickly creature,
I give heaven
praise.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p:
I mean, Master Slender, what would
you with me?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Truly, for mine own part, I would
little or
nothing with you. Your father and
my uncle hath made
motions: if it be my luck,
so; if not, happy man be his
dole! They can
tell you how things go better than I can:
you
may ask your father; here he comes.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Now, Master Slender: love him, daughter Anne.
Why, how now! what does Master Fenton here?
You wrong me, sir, thus still to haunt my house:
I told you, sir, my daughter is disposed of.

sp.speaker: Fent.
sp.l: Nay, Master Page, be not impatient.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p: Good Master Fenton, come not to my child.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: She is no match for you.

sp.speaker: Fent.
sp.l: Sir, will you hear me?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: No, good Master Fenton.
Come, Master Shallow; come, son Slender in.

Knowing my mind, you wrong me, Master Fenton.
[Exeunt Page, Shal., and Slen.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: Speak to Mistress Page.

sp.speaker: Fent.
sp.l: Good Mistress Page, for that I love your daughter
In such a righteous fashion as I do,
Perforce, against all checks, rebukes and manners,
I must advance the colours of my love
And not retire: let me have your good will.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Good mother, do not marry me to yond fool.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.l:
I mean it not; I seek you a better
husband.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: That's my master, master doctor.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Alas, I had rather be set quick i' the earth
And bowl'd to death with turnips!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.l: Come, trouble not yourself. Good Master Fenton,
I will not be your friend nor enemy:
My daughter will I question how she loves you,
And as I find her, so am I affected.
Till then farewell, sir: she must needs go in;
Her father will be angry.

sp.speaker: Fent.
sp.l:
Farewell, gentle mistress; farewell, Nan.
[Exeunt Mrs. Page and Anne.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
This is my doing, now: 'Nay,' said
I, 'will you
cast away your child on a fool,
and a physician?
Look on Master Fenton:'
this is my doing

sp.speaker: Fent.
sp.l: I thank thee; and I pray thee, once to-night
Give my sweet Nan this ring: there's for thy pains.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Now heaven send thee good fortune!
[Exit Fenton.] A kind
heart he hath;
a woman would run through fire and water
for such a kind heart. But yet I would my
master
had Mistress Anne; or I would Master
Slender had her; or, in
sooth, I would
Master Fenton had her: I will do what I can
for them all three; for so I have promised,
and I'll be as
good as my word; but speciously
for Master Fenton. Well, I
must of
another errand to Sir John Falstaff from my
two
mistresses: what a beast am I to slack it!
[Exit.

div2.head: SCENE V
div2.stage: A room in the Garter Inn.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Bardolph, I say,--

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: Here, sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Go fetch me a quart of sack'; put a
toast in't. [Exit Bard.]
Have I lived to be
carried in a basket, like a barrow of
butcher's
offal, and to be thrown in the Thames? Well,
if I be served such another trick, I'll have my
brains
ta'en out and buttered, and give them
to a dog for a
new-year's gift. The rogues
slighted me into the river
with as little remorse
as they would have drowned a
blind
bitch's puppies, fifteen i' the litter: and you
may
know by my size that I have a kind of
alacrity in sinking;
if the bottom were as
deep as hell, I should down.
I had been
drowned, but that the shore was shelvy and
shallow,--a death that I abhor; for the water
swells a
man; and what a thing should I
have been when I
had been swelled! I
should have been a mountain of
mummy. Re-enter BARDOLPH with sack.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p:
Here's Mistress Quickly, sir, to
speak with you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Come, let me pour in some sack to
the Thames
water; for my belly's as cold
as if I had swallowed snowballs
for pills to
cool the reins. Call her in.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l:
Come in, woman!
Enter MISTRESS QUICKLY.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
By your leave; I cry you mercy:
give your worship good morrow.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Take away these chalices.
Go brew
me a pottle of sack finely.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: With eggs, sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Simple of itself; I'll no pullet-sperm
in my
brewage. [Exit Bardolph.] How now!

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Marry, sir, I come to your worship
from Mistress Ford.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Mistress Ford! I have had ford
enough; I was thrown
into the ford; I have
my belly full of ford.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Alas the day! good heart, that
was not her
fault: she does so take on with
her men; they mistook
their erection.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
So did I mine, to build upon a foolish
woman's promise.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Well, she laments, sir, for it, that
it would yearn
your heart to see it. Her
husband goes this morning a-birding;
she desires
you once more to come to her between
eight and nine: I must carry her word
quickly:
she'll make you amends, I warrant
you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Well, I will visit her: tell her so;

and bid her 
think what a man is: let her consider

his frailty, and 
then judge of my merit.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: I will tell her.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Do so. Between nine and ten, sayest
thou?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: Eight and nine, sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Well, be gone: I will not miss her.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l:
Peace be with you, sir.
[Exit.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I marvel I hear not of Master Brook;
he sent me
word to stay within: i like his
money well.
O, here he comes.
Enter FORD.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Bless you, sir!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Now, Master Brook, you come to
know
what hath passed between me and
Ford's wife?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: That, indeed, Sir John, is my business.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Master Brook, I will not lie to you;
I was at her house the hour she appointed me.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: And sped you, sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Very ill-favouredly, Master Brook.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
How so, sir? Did she change her
determination?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
No, Master Brook; but the peaking
Cornuto her husband,
Master Brook, dwelling
in a continual 'larum of jealousy,
comes
me in the instant of our encounter, after we
had
embraced, kissed, protested, and, as it
were, spoke the prologue
of our comedy; and
at his heels a rabble of his companions,
thither
provoked and instigated by his distemper,
and, forsooth, to search his house for his wife's
love.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: What, while you were there?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: While I was there.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
And did he search for you, and
could not find you?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
You shall hear. As good luck would
have it,
comes in one Mistress Page; gives intelligence
of Ford's approach;
and, in her invention
and Ford's wife's distraction,
they conveyed
me into a buck-basket.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: A buck-basket!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
By the Lord, a buck-basket! rammed
me in with foul
shirts and smocks, socks, foul
stockings, greasy
napkins; that, Master Brook,
there was the rankest
compound of villanous
smell that ever offended
nostril.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: And how long lay you there?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Nay, you shall hear, Master Brook,
what I
have suffered to bring this woman to
evil for your
good. Being thus crammed in the
basket, a couple of
Ford's knaves, his hinds,
were called forth by their mistress
to carry me
in the name of foul clothes to
Datchet-lane:
they took me on their shoulders; met
the jealous
knave their master in the door, who
asked
them once or twice what they had in their basket:
I quaked for fear, lest the lunatic knave
would have searched it; but fate, ordaining he
should
be a cuckold, held his hand. Well: on
went he for
a search, and away went I for foul
clothes. But
mark the sequel, Master Brook:
I suffered the pangs
of three several deaths;
first, an intolerable fright,
to be detected with a
jealous rotten bell-wether;
next, to be compassed,
like a good bilbo, in the circumference
of
a peck, hilt to point, heel to head; and
then,
to be stopped in, like a strong distillation, with
stinking
clothes that fretted in their own grease.
think of that,--a man of my kidney,--think of
that,--
that am as subject to heat as butter; a
man of continual
dissolution and thaw: it was
a miracle to 'scape
suffocation. And in the
height of this bath, when I
was more than half
stewed in grease, like a Dutch dish,
to be
thrown into the Thames, and
cooled, glowing
hot, in that surge, like a horse-shoe;
think of
that,--hissing hot,--think of that, Master
Brook.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
In good sadness, sir, I am sorry that
for my sake
you have suffered all this.
My suit
then is desperate; you'll undertake her no
more?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Master Brook, I will be thrown into
Etna,
as I have been into Thames, ere I will
leave her thus.
Her husband is this morning
gone a-birding: I
have received from her another
embassy of meeting;
'twixt eight and
nine is the hour, Master
Brook.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: 'Tis past eight already, sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Is it? I will then address me to my appointment.
Come to me at your convenient
leisure, and
you shall know how I speed; and
the conclusion
shall be crowned with your enjoying
her. Adieu. You
shall have her, Master
Brook; Master Brook, you shall
cuckold Ford. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Hum! ha! is this a vision? is this a
dream?
do I sleep? Master Ford, awake!
awake, Master Ford!
there's a hole made in
your best coat, Master Ford. This
'tis to be
married! this 'tis to have linen and buck-baskets!
Well, I will proclaim myself what I am:
I will now take the lecher; he is at my house;
he
cannot 'scape me; 'tis impossible he should;
he cannot
creep into a halfpenny purse, nor into
a pepper-box:
but, lest the devil that guides
him should
aid him, I will search impossible
places. Though
what I am I cannot avoid, yet
to be what I would
not shall not make me tame:
if I have horns to make
one mad, let the proverb
go with me: I'll be
horn-mad.
[Exit.

div2.head: SCENE I
div2.stage: Enter MISTRESS PAGE, MISTRESS QUICKLY, and WILLIAM.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Is he at Master Ford's already,
think'st thou?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Sure he is by this, or will be presently:
but,
truly, he is very courageous mad
about his throwing
into the water. Mistress
Ford desires you to come
suddenly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
I'll be with her by and by; I'll
but bring
my young man here to school. Look,
where his master
comes; 'tis a playing-day,
I see.
Enter SIR HUGH EVANS.
How now. Sir Hugh! no
school to-day?

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
No; Master Slender is let the boys
leave to play.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: Blessing of his heart!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Sir Hugh, my husband says
my son profits
nothing in the world at his
book. I pray you, ask
him some questions in
his accidence--

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Come hither, William; hold up
your head; come.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Come on, sirrah; hold up your
head; answer
your master, be not afraid.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
William, how many numbers is in
nouns?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Two.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Truly. I thought there had been one
number
more, because they say, ''Od's nouns.'

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Peace your tattlings! What is 'fair,'
William?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Pulcher.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Polecats! there are fairer things
than polecats,
sure.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
You are a very simplicity 'oman; I
pray you,
peace. What is 'lapis,' William?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: A stone.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.l: And what is 'a stone,' William?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: A pebble.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
No, it is 'lapis:' I pray you, remember
in your
prain.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Lapis.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
That is a good William. What is
he, William, that
does lend articles?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p:
Articles are borrowed of the pronoun,
and be
thus declined, Singulariter, nominativo,
hic, haec, hoc.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Nominativo, hig, hag, hog; pray
you, mark: genitivo,
hujus. Well what is
your accusative case?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Accusativo, hinc.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
I pray you, have your remembrance,
child; accusative,
hung, hang, hog.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
'Hang-hog' is Latin for bacon, I
warrant you.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Leave your prabbles. 'oman. What
is the focative
case, William?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: O,--vocativo, O.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Remember, William; focative is
caret.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: And that's a good root.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.l: 'Oman, forbear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.l: Peace!

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
What is your genitive case plural,
William?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Genitive case!

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.l: Ay.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Genitive,--horum, harum, horum.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Vengeance of Jenny's case! fie on
her! never
name her, child, if she be a whore.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.l: For shame, 'oman.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
You do ill to teach the child such
words: he
teaches him to hick and to hack,
which they'll do fast
enough of themselves, and
to call 'horum:' fie upon you!

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
'Oman, art thou lunatics? hast thou
no understandings
for thy cases and the numbers
of the genders?
Thou art as foolish
Christian creatures as I would
desires.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p: Prithee, hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Show me now, William, some declensions
of your
pronouns.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Forsooth, I have forgot.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
It is qui, quae, quod: if you forget
your 'quies,'
your 'quaes,' and your 'quods,'
you must be preeches. Go
your ways, and
play; go.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
He is a better scholar than I
thought he was.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
He is a good sprag memory. Fare-
well, Mistress Page.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Adieu, good Sir Hugh. [Exit Sir Hugh.]
Get you home, boy. Come, we stay
too long.
[Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Mistress Ford, your sorrow hath eaten
up my sufferance.
I see you are obsequious in
your love, and I profess
requital to a hair's
breadth; not only, Mistress Ford,
in the simple
office of love, but in all the accoutrement,
complement and ceremony of it. But are you
sure of
your husband now?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p: He's a-birding, sweet Sir John.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
What, ho, gossip
Ford! what, ho!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Step into the chamber, Sir John.
[Exit Falstaff.
Enter MISTRESS PAGE.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
How now, sweetheart! who's at
home
besides yourself?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p: Why, none but mine own people.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.l: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
No, certainly. [Aside to her]
Speak louder.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Truly, I am so glad you have
nobody here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Why, woman, your husband is
in his old
lunes again: he so takes on yonder
with my husband; so
rails against all married
mankind; so curses all Eve's
daughters, of
what complexion soever; and so buffets
himself
on the forehead, crying, 'Peer out, peer
out!'
that any madness I ever yet beheld
seemed but tameness,
civility and patience, to
this his distemper he is in
now: I am glad the
fat knight is not here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.l: Why, does he talk of him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Of none but him; and swears
he was carried
out, the last time he searched
for him, in a basket;
protests to my husband
he is now here, and hath drawn
him and the
rest of their company from their sport to
make another experiment of his suspicion: but
I am glad
the knight is not here; now he shall
see his own
foolery.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p: How near is he, Mistress Page?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Hard by; at street end; he will
be here anon.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p: I am undone! The knight is here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Why then you are utterly
shamed, and he's
but a dead man. What a
woman are yo!--Away with
him, away with
him! better shame than murder.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Which way should he go? how
should I
bestow him? Shall I put him into
the basket again?
Re-enter FALSTAFF.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: No, I'll come no more i' the basket.
May I not go out ere he come?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Alas, three of Master Ford's
brothers watch
the door with pistols, that none
shall issue out; otherwise
you might slip away
ere he came. But what make
you here?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
What shall I do? I'll creep up into
the chimney.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
There they always use to discharge
their
birding-pieces. Creep into the
kiln-hole.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Where is it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
He will seek there, on my word.
Neither
press, coffer, chest, trunk, well, vault,
but he hath
an abstract for the remembrance of
such places, and goes
to them by his note:
there is no hiding you in the
house.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I'll go out then.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
If you go out in your own semblance,
you die, Sir John. Unless you go out
disguised--

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p: How might we disguise him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Alas the day, I know not!
There is no woman's
gown big enough for him;
otherwise he might
put on a hat, a muffler and
a kerchief, and so escape.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Good hearts, devise something; any
extremity
rather than a mischief.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
My maid's aunt, the fat woman
of Brentford,
has a gown above.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
On my word, it will serve him;

she's as 
big as he is: and there's her thrummed

hat and her muffler 
too. Run up, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Go, go, sweet Sir John: Mistress
Page and
I will look some linen for your head.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Quick, quick! we'll come dress
you
straight: put on the gown the while.
[Exit Falstaff.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
I would my husband would meet
him
in this shape: he cannot abide the old
woman of Brentford;
he swears she's a witch;
forbade her my house and
hath threatened to
beat her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Heaven guide him to thy husband's
cudgel,
and the devil guide his cudgel
afterwards!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p: But is my husband coming?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Ay, in good sadness, is he; and
talks of the
basket too, howsoever he hath had
intelligence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
We'll try that; for I'll appoint
my men to
carry the basket again, to meet him
at the door with
it, as they did last time.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Nay, but he'll be here presently:
let's go
dress him like the witch of Brentford.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
I'll first direct my men what
they
shall do with the basket. Go up; I'll
bring linen for
him straight.
[Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Hang him, dishonest varlet!
we
cannot misuse him enough.
sp.l: We'll leave a proof, by that which we will do,
Wives may be merry, and yet honest too:
We do not act that often jest and laugh;

'Tis old, but true, Still swine eats all the draff.
[Exit.
Re-enter MISTRESS FORD with two Servants.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Go, sirs, take the basket again
on your
shoulders: your master is hard at
door; if he bid you
set it down, obey him:
quickly, dispatch.
[Exit.

sp.speaker: First Serv.
sp.l: Come, come, take it up.

sp.speaker: Sec. Serv.
sp.p:
Pray heaven it be not full of
knight again.

sp.speaker: First Serv.
sp.l:
I hope not; I had as lief bear
so much lead.
Enter FORD, PAGE, SHALLOW, CAIUS, and SIR HUGH EVANS.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Ay, but if it prove true, Master Page,
have you any
way then to unfool me again?
Set down the basket,
villain! Somebody call
my wife. Youth in a basket!
O you pandarly
rascals! there's a knot, a ging, a pack,
a conspiracy
against me: now shall the devil be
shamed.
What, wife, I say! Come, come
forth! Behold what honest
clothes you send
forth to bleaching!

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Why, this passes, Master Ford; you
are not to go
loose any longer; you must be
pinioned.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Why, this is lunatics! this is mad as
a
mad dog.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Indeed, Master Ford, this is not well,
indeed.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
So say I too, sir.
Re-enter MISTRESS FORD.
Come hither, Mistress Ford; Mistress
Ford, the
honest woman, the modest wife, the virtuous
creature, that hath the jealous fool to her husband!
I suspect without cause, mistress, do I?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Heaven be my witness you do,
if you
suspect me in any dishonesty.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Well said, brazen-face! hold it out.

Come forth,
sirrah!
[Pulling clothes out of the basket.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: This passes!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Are you not ashamed? let the
clothes alone.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: I shall find you anon.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
'Tis unreasonable! Will you take
up your wife's
clothes? Come away.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Empty the basket, I say!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.l: Why, man, why?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Master Page, as I am a man, there was
one conveyed
out of my house yesterday in
this basket: why
may not he be there again?
in my house I am sure he is:
my intelligence
is true; my jealousy is reasonable. Pluck
me
out all the linen.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
If you find a man there, he shall
die a flea's
death.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Here's no man.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
By my fidelity, this is not well, Master
Ford; this
wrongs you.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Master Ford, you must pray, and
not follow the
imaginations of your own heart:
this is jealousies.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
No, nor nowhere else but in your
brain.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Help to search my house this one
time. If I find
not what I seek show no colour
for my extremity; let
me for ever be your table-sport;
let them say of me, 'As
jealous as
sp.l:
Ford, that searched a hollow walnut for his
wife's leman.' Satisfy me once more; once
more search
with me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
What, ho, Mistress Page! come
you and
the old woman down; my husband
will come into the
chamber.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Old woman! what old woman's that?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Why, it is my maid's aunt of
Brentford.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
A witch, a quean, an old cozening
quean!
Have I not forbid her my house? She
comes of errands,
does she? We are simple
men; we do not know what's
brought to pass
under the profession of fortune-telling.
She
works by charms, by spells, by the figure, and
such
daubery as this is, beyond our element:
we know nothing.
Come down, you witch,
you hag, you; come
down, I say!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Nay, good, sweet husband! Good
gentlemen,
let him not strike the old woman.
Re-enter FALSTAFF in woman's clothes, and MISTRESS PAGE.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Come, Mother Prat; come, give
me your
hand.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I'll prat her. [Beating him] Out of
my door, you witch,
you hag, you baggage,
you polecat, you ronyon!
out, out! I'll conjure
you, I'll fortune-tell you.
[Exit Falstaff.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Are you not ashamed?
I think
you have killed the poor woman.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Nay, he will do it. 'Tis a
goodly credit
for you

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Hang her, witch!

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
By yea and no, I think the 'oman is
a witch indeed:
I like not when a 'oman has
a great peard; I spy
a great peard under his
muffler.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Will you follow, gentlemen? I beseech
you, follow;
see but the issue of my
jealousy: if I cry out thus
upon no trail, never
trust me when I open again.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Let's obey his humour a little further:
come, gentlemen.
[Exeunt Ford, Page, Shal., Caius, and Evans.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Trust me, he beat him most
pitifully.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Nay, by the mass, that he did
not; he beat
him most unpitifully, methought.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
I'll have the cudgel hallowed
and hung
o'er the altar; it hath done meritorious
service.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
What think you? may we, with
the warrant
of womanhood and the witness of
a good conscience,
pursue him with any
further revenge?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
The spirit of wantonness is,
sure, scared out
of him: if the devil have him
not in fee-simple, with
fine and recovery, he
will never, I think, in the way of
waste, attempt
us again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Shall we tell our husbands how
we have
served him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Yes, by all means; if it be but
to scrape
the figures out of your husband's
brains. If they can find
in their hearts the
poor unvirtuous fat knight shall be
any
further afflicted, we two will still be the
ministers.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
I'll warrant they'll have him
publicly
shamed: and methinks there would be
no period to the
jest, should he not be publicly
shamed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Come, to the forge with it then;

shape it: 
I would not have things cool.

[Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE III
div2.stage: A room in the Garter Inn.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p:
Sir, the Germans desire to have three
of your
horses: the duke himself will be to-morrow
at court,
and they are going to meet
him.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
What duke should that be comes so
secretly?
I hear not of him in the court. Let
me speak with the
gentlemen: they speak
English?

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: Ay, sir; I'll call them to you.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
They shall have my horses; but I'll
make them
pay; I'll sauce them: they have
had my house a week at
command; I have
turned away my other guests: they
must come
off; I'll sauce them. Come.
[Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE IV
div2.stage: Enter PAGE, FORD, MISTRESS PAGE, MISTRESS FORD, and SIR HUGH EVANS.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
'Tis one of the best discretions of a
'oman as ever
I did look upon.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
And did he send you both these letters
at an
instant?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.l: Within a quarter of an hour.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Pardon me, wife. Henceforth do what thou wilt;
I rather will suspect the sun with cold
Than thee with wantonness: now doth thy honour stand,
In him that was of late an heretic,
As firm as faith.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: 'Tis well, 'tis well; no more:
Be not as extreme in submission
As in offence.
But let our plot go forward: let our wives
Yet once again, to make us public sport,
Appoint a meeting with this old fat fellow,
Where we may take him and disgrace him for it.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
There is no better way than that
they spoke of.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
How? to send him word they'll meet
him in
the park at midnight? Fie, fie! he'll
never come.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
You say he has been thrown in the
rivers and
has been grievously peaten as an old
'oman: methinks
there should be terrors in him
that he should not come;
methinks his flesh is
punished, he shall have no
desires.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: So think I too.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.l: Devise but how you'll use him when he comes,
And let us two devise to bring him thither.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.l:
There is an old tale goes that Herne the
hunter,
Sometime a keeper here in Windsor forest,
Doth all the winter-time, at still midnight,
Walk round about an oak, with great ragg'd horns;
And there he blasts the tree and takes the cattle
And makes milch-kine yield blood and shakes a chain
In a most hideous and dreadful manner:
You have heard of such a spirit, and well you know
The superstitious idle-headed eld
Received and did deliver to our age
This tale of Herne the hunter for a truth.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Why, yet there want not many that do fear
In deep of night to walk by this Herne's oak:
But what of this?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Marry, this is our device;
That Falstaff at that oak shall meet with us.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Well, let it not be doubted but he'll come:
And in this shape when you have brought him thither,
What shall be done with him? what is your plot?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.l: That likewise have we thought upon, and thus:
Nan Page my daughter and my little son
And three or four more of their growth we'll dress
Like urchins, ouphes and fairies, green and white,
With rounds of waxen tapers on their heads,
And rattles in their hands: upon a sudden,
As Falstaff, she and I, are newly met,
Let them from forth a sawpit rush at once
With some diffused song: upon their sight,
We two in great amazedness will fly:
Then let them all encircle him about
And, fairy-like, to pinch the unclean knight,
And ask him why, that hour of fairy revel,
In their so sacred paths he dares to tread
In shape profane.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.l: And till he tell the truth,
Let the supposed fairies pinch him sound
And burn him with their tapers.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.l: The truth being known,
We'll all present ourselves, dis-horn the spirit,
And mock him home to Windsor.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: The children must
Be practised well to this, or they'll ne'er do't.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
I will teach the children their behaviours;

and I 
will be like a jack-an-apes

also, to burn the knight 
with my taber.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
That will be excellent.
I'll go buy
them vizards.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.l:
My Nan shall be the queen of all the
fairies,
Finely attired in a robe of white.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: That silk will I go buy. [Aside]
And in that time
Shall Master Slender steal my Nan away
And marry her at Eton. Go send to Falstaff straight.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Nay, I'll to him again in name of Brook:
He'll tell me all his purpose: sure, he'll come.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.l: Fear not you that. Go get us properties
And tricking for our fairies.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Let us about it:
it is admirable
pleasures and fery honest knaveries.
[Exeunt Page, Ford, and Evans.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.l: Go, Mistress Ford,

Send quickly to Sir John, to know his mind.
[Exit Mrs. Ford.
I'll to the doctor: he hath my good will.
And none but he, to marry with Nan Page.
That Slender, though well landed, is an idiot;
And he my husband best of all affects.
The doctor is well money'd and his friends
Potent at court: he, none but he, shall have her,

Though twenty thousand worthier come to crave her.
[Exit.

div2.head: SCENE V
div2.stage: A room in the Garter Inn.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
What wouldst thou have, boor? what,
thick-skin?
speak, breathe, discuss; brief,
short, quick,
snap.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Marry, sir, I come to speak with Sir

John Falstaff
from Master Slender.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
There's his chamber, his house, his
castle,
his standing-bed and truckle-bed; 'tis
painted about
with the story of the Prodigal,
fresh and new. Go knock
and call; he'll
speak like an Anthropophaginian unto
thee:
knock, I say.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
There's an old woman, a fat woman,
gone up
into his chamber. I'll be so bold as
stay, sir, till she come
down; I come to speak
with her, indeed.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Ha! a fat woman! the knight may be
robbed;
I'll call. Bully knight! bully Sir
John! speak from thy
lungs military: art thou
there? it is thine host, thine
Ephesian, calls.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: [Above] How now, mine host!

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Here's a Bohemian-Tartar tarries the
coming
down of thy fat woman. Let her descend,
bully, let
her descend; my chambers
are honourable: fie! privacy?
fie!
Enter FALSTAFF.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
There was, mine host, an old fat woman
even
now with me! but she's gone.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
Pray you, sir, was't not the wise wom-
an of
Brentford?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Ay, marry, was it, mussel-shell: what
would you
with her?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
My master, sir, Master Slender, sent
to her,
seeing her go thorough the streets, to
know, sir, whether
one Nym, sir, that beguiled
him of a chain, had the
chain or no.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I spake with the old woman about it.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: And what says she, I pray, sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Marry, she says that the very same
man that
beguiled Master Slender of his
chain cozened him of it.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
I would I could have spoken with the
woman
herself; I had other things to have
spoken with her
too from him.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: What are they? let us know.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Ay, come; quick.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I may not conceal them, sir.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Conceal them, or thou diest.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
Why, sir, they were nothing but about
Mistress
Anne Page; to know if it were my
master's fortune to
have her or no.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: 'Tis, 'tis his fortune.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: What, sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
To have her, or no. Go; say the
woman told
me so.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: May I be bold to say so, sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Ay, sir; like who more bold.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
I thank your worship: I shall make
my master
glad with these tidings.
[Exit.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Thou art clerkly, thou art clerkly, Sir

John.
Was there a wise woman with thee?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Ay, that there was, mine host; one that
hath taught
me more wit than ever I learned
before in my life; and
I paid nothing for it
neither, but was paid for my
learning.
Enter BARDOLPH.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: Out, alas, sir! cozenage, mere cozenage!

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Where be my horses? speak well of
them,
varletto.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p:
Run away with the cozeners; for so
soon as
I came beyond Eton, they threw me off
from behind
one of them, in a slough of mire;
and set spurs and
away, like three German
devils, three Doctor
Faustuses.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
They are gone but to meet the duke,
villain:
do not say they be fled; Germans are
honest men.
Enter SIR HUGH EVANS.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.l: Where is mine host?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: What is the matter, sir?

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Have a care of your entertainments:
there is a
friend of mine come to town, tells me
there is three
cozen-germans that has cozened
all the hosts of Readins,
of Maidenhead, of
Colebrook, of horses and money. I
tell you for
good will, look you: you are wise and full
of
gibes and vlouting-stocks, and 'tis not convenient
you should be cozened. Fare you well.
[Exit.
Enter DOCTOR CAIUS.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.l: Vere is mine host de Jarteer?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Here, master doctor, in perplexity
and
doubtful dilemma.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
I cannot tell vat is dat: but it is
tell-a me dat
you make grand preparation for
a duke de Jamany: by
my trot, dere is no
duke dat the court is know to
come. I tell you
for good vill: adieu.
[Exit.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Hue and cry, villain, go! Assist me,
knight, I
am undone! Fly, run, hue and cry,
villain! I am
undone!
[Exeunt Host and Bard.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I would all the world might be cozened;
for I
have been cozened and beaten too. If it
should come
to the ear of the court, how I have
been transformed
and how my transformation
hath been washed and
cudgelled, they would
melt me out of my fat drop by
drop and liquor
fishermen's boots with me: I warrant
they would
whip me with their fine wits till I were as
crestfallen as a dried pear. I never prospered
since I
forswore myself at primero. Well, if
my wind were
but long enough to say my
prayers, I would repent.
Enter MISTRESS QUICKLY.
Now, whence come
you?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: From the two parties, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
The devil take one party and his dam
the
other! and so they shall be both bestowed.
I have suffered
more for their sakes, more than
the villanous inconstancy
of man's disposition
is able to bear.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
And have not they suffered? Yes, I
warrant; speciously
one of them; Mistress
Ford, good heart, is beaten
black and blue,
that you cannot see a white spot about
her.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
What tellest thou me of black and
blue? I
was beaten myself into all the colours
of the rainbow;
and I was like to be apprehended
for the witch
of Brentford: but that
my admirable dexterity of wit,
my counterfeiting
the action of an old woman, delivered
me,
the knave constable had set me i' the stocks, i'
the common
stocks, for a witch.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Sir, let me speak with you in your
chamber:
you shall hear how things go; and, I
warrant, to your
content. Here is a letter will
say somewhat. Good
hearts, what ado here is to
bring you together! Sure,
one of you does not
serve heaven well, that you are so
crossed.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l:
Come up into my chamber.
[Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE VI
div2.stage: Another room in the Garter Inn.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Master Fenton, talk not to me; my
mind is
heavy: I will give over all.

sp.speaker: Fent.
sp.l: Yet hear me speak. Assist me in my purpose,
And, as I am a gentleman, I'll give thee
A hundred pound in gold more than your loss.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I will hear you, Master Fenton; and

I will at
the least keep your counsel.

sp.speaker: Fent.
sp.l: From time to time I have acquainted you
With the dear love I bear to fair Anne Page;
Who mutually hath answer'd my affection,
So far forth as herself might be her chooser,
Even to my wish: I have a letter from her
Of such contents as you will wonder at;
The mirth whereof so larded with my matter,
That neither singly can be manifested,
Without the show of both; fat Falstaff
Hath a great scene: the image of the jest
I'll show you here at large. Hark, good mine host.
To-night at Herne's oak, just 'twixt twelve and one,
Must my sweet Nan present the Fairy Queen;
The purpose why, is here: in which disguise,
While other jests are something rank on foot,
Her father hath commanded her to slip
Away with Slender and with him at Eton
Immediately to marry: she hath consented:
Now, sir,
Her mother, ever strong against that match
And firm for Doctor Caius, hath appointed
That he shall likewise shuffle her away,
While other sports are tasking of their minds,
And at the deanery, where a priest attends,
Straight marry her: to this her mother's plot
She seemingly obedient likewise hath
Made promise to the doctor. Now, thus it rests:
Her father means she shall be all in white,
And in that habit, when Slender sees his time
To take her by the hand and bid her go,
She shall go with him: her mother hath intended,
The better to denote her to the doctor,
For they must all be mask'd and vizarded,
That quaint in green she shall be loose enrobed,
With ribands pendent, flaring 'bout her head:
And when the doctor spies his vantage ripe,
To pinch her by the hand, and, on that token,
The maid hath given consent to go with him.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l:
Which means she to deceive, father or
mother?

sp.speaker: Fent.
sp.l: Both, my good host, to go along with me:
And here it rests, that you'll procure the vicar
To stay for me at church 'twixt twelve and one,
And, in the lawful name of marrying,
To give our hearts united ceremony.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Well, husband your device; I'll to the vicar:
Bring you the maid, you shall not lack a priest.

sp.speaker: Fent.
sp.l: So shall I evermore be bound to thee;

Besides, I'll make a present recompense.
[Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE I
div2.stage: A room in the Garter Inn.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Prithee, no more prattling; go, I'll
hold. This is
the third time; I hope good
luck lies in odd numbers.
Away! go. They
say there is divinity in odd numbers,
either in
nativity, chance, or death. Away!

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
I'll provide you a chain; and I'll
do what I can
to get you a pair of horns.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Away, I say; time wears: hold up
your head, and
mince. [Exit Mrs Quickly.
Enter FORD.
How now, Master Brook! Master Brook, the
matter
will be known to-night, or never. Be
you in the
Park about midnight, at Herne's
oak, and you shall
see wonders.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Went you not to her yesterday, sir,
as you told
me you had appointed?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I went to her, Master Brook, as you
see, like a
poor old man: but I came from
her, Master Brook,
like a poor old woman.
That same knave Ford, her husband,
hath the
finest mad devil of jealousy in him, Master
Brook, that ever governed frenzy. I will tell
you:
he beat me grievously, in the shape of a
woman; for in
the shape of man, Master
Brook, I fear not Goliath
with a weaver's
beam; because I know also life is a
shuttle.
I am in haste; go along with me; I'll tell you
all,
Master Brook. Since I plucked geese,
played truant
and whipped top, I knew not
what 'twas to be beaten till
lately. Follow
me: I'll tell you strange things of this
knave
Ford, on whom to-night I will be revenged,
and I
will deliver his wife into your hand. Follow.
Strange
things in hand, Master Brook! Follow.
[Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Come, come; we'll couch i' the castle-ditch
till we see the light of our fairies,
Remember, son Slender,
my daughter.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Ay, forsooth; I have spoke with her
and we have
a nay-word how to know one
another: I come to her
in white, and cry
'mum;' she cries 'budget;' and by that
we
know one another.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
That's good too: but what needs
either your
'mum' or her 'budget?' the white
will decipher her well
enough. It hath struck
ten o'clock.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
The night is dark; light and spirits
will become
it well. Heaven prosper our
sport! No man means
evil but the devil, and
we shall know him by his horns.
Let's away;
follow me.
[Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE III
div2.stage: A street leading to the Park.
Enter MISTRESS PAGE, MISTRESS FORD, and DOCTOR CAIUS.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Master doctor, my daughter is
in green: when
you see your time, take her by
the hand, away with her
to the deanery, and
dispatch it quickly. Go before into
the Park:
we two must go together.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.l: I know vat I have to do. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Fare you well, sir. [Exit Caius.]
My husband will not
rejoice so much
at the abuse of Falstaff as he will chafe
at
the doctor's marrying my daughter: but 'tis no
matter;
better a little chiding than a great deal
of
heart-break.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Where is Nan now and her
troop of fairies,
and the Welsh devil Hugh?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
They are all couched in a pit
hard by Herne's
oak, with obscured lights;
which, at the very instant
of Falstaff's and our
meeting, they will at once display to
the night.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
That cannot choose but amaze
him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
If he be not amazed, he will be
mocked; if
he be amazed, he will every way
be mocked.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p: We'll betray him finely.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.l: Against such lewdsters and their lechery
Those that betray them do no treachery.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
The hour draws on. To the
oak, to the
oak!
[Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE IV
div2.stage: Enter SIR HUGH EVANS, disguised, with others as Fairies.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Trib, trib, fairies; come; and remember
your
parts: be pold, I pray you; follow
me into the pit; and
when I give the
watch-'ords, do as I pid you: come,
come;
trib, trib.
[Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
The Windsor bell hath struck twelve;
the minute
draws on. Now, the hot-blooded
gods assist me!
Remember, Jove, thou wast a
bull for thy Europa; love
set on thy horns.
O powerful love! that, in some respects,
makes
a beast a man, in some other, a man a beast.
You were also, Jupiter, a swan for the love of
Leda. O
omnipotent Love! how near the
god drew to the complexion
of a goose! A
fault done first in the form of a
beast. O
Jove, a beastly fault! And then another fault
in the semblance of a fowl; think on't, Jove;
a foul
fault! When gods have hot backs,
what shall poor
men do? For me, I am here
a Windsor stag; and the
fattest, I think, i'
the forest. Send me a cool rut-time,
Jove, or
who can blame me to piss my tallow? Who
comes here? my doe?
Enter MISTRESS FORD and MISTRESS PAGE.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Sir John! art thou there, my
deer?
my male deer?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
My doe with the black scut! Let the
sky
rain potatoes; let it thunder to the tune of
Green
Sleeves, hail kissing-comfits and snow
eringoes; let
there come a tempest of provocation,
I will shelter me
here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Mistress Page is come with
me, sweetheart.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Divide me like a bribe buck, each a
haunch:
I will keep my sides to myself, my
shoulders for the
fellow of this walk, and my
horns I bequeath your
husbands. Am I a
woodman, ha? Speak I like Herne
the hunter?
Why, now is Cupid a child of conscience;
he makes restitution. As I am a
true spirit, welcome! [Noise within.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.l: Alas, what noise?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p: Heaven forgive our sins!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: What should this be?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page. Mrs. Ford
sp.p: Away, away! [They run off.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I think the devil will not have me
damned,
lest the oil that's in me should set
hell on fire;
he would never else cross me
thus.
Enter SIR HUGH EVANS, disguised as before; PISTOL, as Hobgoblin; MISTRESS QUICKLY, ANNE PAGE, and others, as Fairies, with tapers.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: Fairies, black, grey, green, and white,
You moonshine revellers, and shades of night,
You orphan heirs of fixed destiny,
Attend your office and your quality.
Crier Hobgoblin, make the fairy oyes.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Elves, list your names; silence, you airy toys.
Cricket, to Windsor chimneys shalt thou leap:
Where fires thou find'st unraked and hearts unswept,
There pinch the maids as blue as bilberry:
Our radiant queen hates sluts and sluttery.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: They are fairies; he that speaks to them shall die:

I'll wink and couch: no man their works must eye.
[Lies down upon his face.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.l: Where's Bede? Go you, and where you find a maid
That, ere she sleep, has thrice her prayers said,
Raise up the organs of her fantasy;
Sleep she as sound as careless infancy:
But those as sleep and think not on their sins,
Pinch them, arms, legs, backs, shoulders, sides and shins.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: About, about;
Search Windsor Castle, elves, within and out:
Strew good luck, ouphes, on every sacred room:
That it may stand till the perpetual doom,
In state as wholesome as in state 'tis fit,
Worthy the owner, and the owner it.
The several chairs of order look you scour
With juice of balm and every precious flower:
Each fair instalment, coat, and several crest,
With loyal blazon, evermore be blest!
And nightly, meadow-fairies, look you sing,
Like to the Garter's compass, in a ring:
The expressure that it bears, green let it be,
More fertile-fresh than all the field to see;
And 'Honi soit qui mal y pense' write
In emerald tufts, flowers purple, blue, and white;
Like sapphire, pearl and rich embroidery,
Buckled below fair knighthood's bending knee:
Fairies use flowers for their charactery.
Away; disperse: but till 'tis one o'clock,
Our dance of custom round about the oak
Of Herne the hunter, let us not forget.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.l: Pray you, lock hand in hand; yourselves in order set;
And twenty glow-worms shall our lanterns be,
To guide our measure round about the tree.
But, stay; I smell a man of middle-earth.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Heavens defend me from that Welsh
fairy,
lest he transform me to a piece of
cheese!

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l:
Vile worm, thou wast o'erlook'd even in thy
birth.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: With trial-fire touch me his fingerend:
If he be chaste, the flame will back descend
And turn him to no pain; but if he start,
It is the flesh of a corrupted heart.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: A trial, come.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.l:
Come, will this wood take fire?
[They burn him with their tapers.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Oh, Oh, Oh!

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: Corrupt, corrupt, and tainted in desire!
About him, fairies; sing a scornful rhyme;

And, as you trip, still pinch him to your time.
SONG.
Fie on sinful fantasy!
Fie on lust and luxury!
Lust is but a bloody fire,
Kindled with unchaste desire.
Fed in heart, whose flames aspire
As thoughts do blow them, higher and higher.
Pinch him, fairies, mutually;
Pinch him for his villany;
Pinch him, and burn him, and turn him about,
Till candles and starlight and moonshine be out.
During this song they pinch FALSTAFF. DOCTOR CAIUS comes one way, and steals away a boy in green; SLENDER another way, and takes off a boy in white; and FENTON comes, and steals away MRS ANNE PAGE. A noise of hunting is heard within. All the Fairies run away. FALSTAFF pulls off his buck's head, and rises.
Enter PAGE, FORD, MISTRESS PAGE and MISTRESS FORD.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l:
Nay, do not fly; I think we have watch'd you
now:

Will none but Herne the hunter serve your
turn?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.l: I pray you, come, hold up the jest no higher.
Now, good Sir John, how like you Windsor wives?
See you these, husband? do not these fair yokes
Become the forest better than the town?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Now, sir, who's a cuckold now?
Master Brook, Falstaff's a knave, a cuckoldly
knave;
here are his horns, Master Brook:
and,
Master Brook, he hath enjoyed nothing of
Ford's
but his buck-basket, his cudgel, and
twenty pounds of
money, which must be paid
to Master Brook; his horses are
arrested for
it, Master Brook.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ford.
sp.p:
Sir John, we have had ill
luck; we could
never meet. I will never take
you for my love again;
but I will always
count you my deer.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I do begin to perceive that I am made
an ass.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Ay, and an ox too: both the proofs
are
extant.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
And these are not fairies?
I was
three or four times in the thought they were
not
fairies: and yet the guiltiness of my mind,
the sudden
surprise of my powers, drove the
grossness of the foppery
into a received belief,
in despite of the teeth of
all rhyme and
reason, that they were fairies. See now
how
wit may be made a Jack-a-Lent, when 'tis
upon ill
employment!

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
Sir John Falstaff, serve Got, and
leave your
desires, and fairies will not pinse
you.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Well, said, fairy Hugh.

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
And leave your jealousies too, I
pray
you.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I will never mistrust my wife again,
till thou
art able to woo her in good English.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Have I laid my brain in the sun and
dried it,
that it wants matter to prevent so
gross o'erreaching as
this? Am I ridden with
a Welsh goat too? shall I have
a coxcomb of
frize? 'Tis time I were choked with a
piece
of toasted cheese.

sp.speaker: Evans.
Fal.
sp.p:
'Seese' and 'putter'! have I lived to
stand at the
taunt of one that makes fritters of
English? This is enough
to be the decay of
lust and late-walking through
the realm.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Why, Sir John, do you think,
though we
would have thrust virtue out of our
hearts by the head
and shoulders and have
given ourselves without scruple
to hell, that
ever the devil could have made you our
delight?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: What, a hodge-pudding? a bag of flax!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.l: A puffed man?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Old, cold, withered and of intolera-
ble
entrails?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
And one that is as slanderous as
Satan?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: And as poor as Job?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: And as wicked as his wife?

sp.speaker: Evans.
sp.p:
And given to fornications, and to
taverns
and sack and wine and metheglins,
and to drinkings
and swearings and starings,
pribbles and prabbles?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Well, I am your theme: you have the
start of
me; I am dejected; I am not able to
answer the Welsh
flannel: ignorance itself is
a plummet o'er me: use me
as you will.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Marry, sir, we'll bring you to Windsor,
to one
Master Brook, that you have cozened
of money, to whom
you should have
been a pandar: over and above that you
have
suffered, I think to repay that money will be
a biting
affliction.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Yet be cheerful, knight: thou shalt
eat a posset
to-night at my house; where I will
desire thee to laugh
at my wife, that now
laughs at thee: tell her Master Slender
hath
married her daughter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
[Aside] Doctors doubt that:
if Anne Page be my daughter, she is, by this,
Doctor
Caius' wife.
Enter SLENDER.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: Whoa, ho! ho, father Page!

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Son, how now! how now, son!
have
you dispatched?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Dispatched! I'll make the best in
Gloucestershire
know on't; would I were
hanged, la, else!

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Of what, son?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I came yonder at Eton to marry Mistress
Anne
Page, and she's a great lubberly
boy. If it had not been
i' the church, I would
have swinged him, or he should
have swinged
me. If I did not think it had been Anne
Page, would I might never stir--and 'tis a
postmaster's
boy.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Upon my life, then, you took the
wrong.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
What need you tell me that? I
think so, when
I took a boy for a girl. If I
had been married to him,
for all he was in
woman's apparel, I would not have
had him.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Why, this is your own folly.
Did
not I tell you how you should know my
daughter
by her garments?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I went to her in white, and cried
'mum,' and
she cried 'budget,' as Anne and I
had appointed; and yet
it was not Anne, but
a postmaster's boy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Good George, be not angry: I
knew of
your purpose; turned my daughter
into green; and, indeed,
she is now with the
doctor at the deanery, and
there married.
Enter CAIUS.

sp.speaker: Caius.
Mrs. Page.
sp.p:
Why, did you take her in
green?

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.l: Ay, by gar, and 'tis a boy: by gar,

I'll raise all
Windsor.
[Exit.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
This is strange. Who hath got the
right Anne?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
My heart misgives me: here comes
Master Fenton. Enter FENTON and ANNE PAGE.
How now, Master Fenton!

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Pardon, good father! good my mother, pardon!

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Now, mistress,
how chance you
went not with Master Slender?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.l: Why went you not with master doctor, maid?

sp.speaker: Fent.
sp.l: You do amaze: hear the truth of it.
You would have married her most shamefully,
Where there was no proportion held in love.
The truth is, she and I, long since contracted,
Are now so sure that nothing can dissolve us.
The offence is holy that she hath committed;
And this deceit loses the name of craft,
Of disobedience, or unduteous title,
Since therein she doth evitate and shun
A thousand irreligious cursed hours,
Which forced marriage would have brought upon her.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Stand not amazed; here is no remedy:
In love the heavens themselves do guide the state;
Money buys lands, and wives are sold by fate.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I am glad, though you have ta'en a
special stand
to strike at me, that your arrow
hath glanced.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l:
Well, what remedy? Fenton, heaven give thee
joy!
'What cannot be eschew'd must be embraced.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l:
When night-dogs run, all sorts of deer are
chased.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page.
sp.l: Well, I will must no further, Master Fenton,
Heaven give you many, many merry days!
Good husband, let us every one go home,
And laugh this sport o'er by a country fire;
Sir John and all.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Let it be so, Sir John,
To Master Brook you yet shall hold your word;

For he to-night shall lie with Mistress Ford.
[Exeunt.
